Sharif Moulay Youssef Alaoui (Arabic: مولاي يوسف العلوي‎) (born c. 1969 in Rabat) is a cousin of Mohammed VI. He is reportedly a close friend of the King, who appointed him as an advisor to him. Youssef regularly appears beside the monarch in official visits, most recently in Tunisia in June 2014.Sharif Moulay Youssef Alaoui is also an important businessman in the country who is active in the hospitality, Tourism and real-estate sectors, sometimes in association with Prince Moulay Rachid. He owns the holding Blue Invest, that controlled the "Tahiti Beach Club" in Casablanca


== Family ==
He is the youngest son of Prince Moulay Ali and Princess Lalla Fatima Zohra and the brother of Sharif Moulay Abdallah Alaoui and Princess Lalla Joumala Alaoui. He studied at the Collège royal in Rabat in the same class as Prince Moulay Rachid.

text.wiki:
Rabat (, also UK: , US: ; Arabic: الرباط‎, romanized: ar-ribāṭ; Berber languages: ⴰⵕⴱⴰⵟ, romanized: aṛṛbaṭ) is the capital city of Morocco and the country's seventh largest city with an urban population of approximately 580,000 (2014) and a metropolitan population of over 1.2 million.  It is also the capital city of the Rabat-Salé-Kénitra administrative region. Rabat is located on the Atlantic Ocean at the mouth of the river Bou Regreg, opposite Salé, the city's main commuter town.
Rabat was founded in the 12th century by the Almohad ruler Abd al-Mu'min as a military town. The city steadily grew but went into an extended period of decline following the collapse of the Almohads. In the 17th century Rabat became a haven for Barbary pirates. The French established a protectorate over Morocco in 1912 and made Rabat its administrative center. Morocco achieved independence in 1955 and Rabat became its capital.
Rabat, Temara, and Salé form a conurbation of over 1.8 million people. Silt-related problems have diminished Rabat's role as a port; however, Rabat, and Salé still maintain important textile, food processing and construction industries. In addition, tourism and the presence of all foreign embassies in Morocco serve to make Rabat one of the most important cities in the country. The Moroccan capital was ranked at second place by CNN in its "Top Travel Destinations of 2013". It is one of four Imperial cities of Morocco, and the medina of Rabat is listed as a World Heritage Site. Rabat is accessible by train through the ONCF system and by plane through the nearby Rabat–Salé Airport.


== Etymology ==
The name Rabat comes from الرِّبَاط (ar-ribāṭ) meaning the ribat, an Islamic base or fortification. This name is short for رِبَاط الفَتْح (ribāṭu l-fatḥ) meaning the ribat of conquest or  stronghold of victory—a title the city acquired in 1170, due to its military importance.


== History ==


=== 12th to 17th century ===
Rabat has a relatively modern history compared to the nearby ancient city of Salé. In 1146, the Almohad ruler Abd al-Mu'min turned Rabat's ribat into a full-scale fortress to use as a launching point for attacks on Iberia.
Yaqub al-Mansur (known as Moulay Yacoub in Morocco), another Almohad Caliph, moved the capital of his empire to Rabat. He built Rabat's city walls, the Kasbah of the Udayas and began construction on what would have been the world's largest mosque. However, Yaqub died and construction stopped. The ruins of the unfinished mosque, along with the Hassan Tower, still stand today.
Yaqub's death initiated a period of decline. The Almohad empire lost control of its possessions in Spain and much of its African territory, eventually leading to its total collapse.  In the 13th century, much of Rabat's economic power shifted to Fez. In 1515 a Moorish explorer, El Wassan, reported that Rabat had declined so much that only 100 inhabited houses remained. An influx of Moriscos, who had been expelled from Spain, in the early 17th century helped boost Rabat's growth.


=== Corsair republics ===
Rabat and neighboring Salé united to form the Republic of Bou Regreg in 1627.  The republic was run by Barbary pirates who used the two cities as base ports for launching attacks on shipping. The pirates did not have to contend with any central authority until the Alaouite Dynasty united Morocco in 1666.  The latter attempted to establish control over the pirates, but failed.  European and Muslim authorities continued to attempt to control the pirates over many years, but the Republic of Bou Regreg did not collapse until 1818.  Even after the republic's collapse, pirates continued to use the port of Rabat, which led to the shelling of the city by Austria in 1829 after an Austrian ship had been lost to a pirate attack.


=== 20th century ===


==== French invasion ====
The French invasion of Morocco began in the east with General Hubert Lyautey's occupation of Oujda March 1907 and in the west with the Bombardment of Casablanca August 1907. The Treaty of Fes established the protectorate March 1912. Acting as French administrator of Morocco, Lyautey, decided to relocate the country's capital from Fes to Rabat.  Among other factors, rebellious citizens had made Fes an unstable place. Sultan Moulay Youssef followed the decision of the French and moved his residence to Rabat.  In 1913, Lyautey hired Henri Prost who designed the Ville Nouvelle (Rabat's modern quarter) as an administrative sector.  When Morocco achieved independence in 1955, Mohammed V, the then King of Morocco, chose to have the capital remain at Rabat.


==== Post World War II ====
Following World War II, the United States established a military presence in Rabat at the former French air base.  By the early 1950s, Rabat Salé Air Base was a U.S. Air Force installation hosting the 17th Air Force and the 5th Air Division, which oversaw forward basing for Strategic Air Command (SAC) B-47 Stratojet aircraft in the country.  With the destabilization of French government in Morocco, and Moroccan independence in 1956, the government of Mohammed V wanted the U.S. Air Force to pull out of the SAC bases in Morocco, insisting on such action after American intervention in Lebanon in 1958. The United States agreed to leave as of December 1959, and was fully out of Morocco by 1963. SAC felt the Moroccan bases were much less critical with the long range capability of the B-52 Stratofortresses that were replacing the B-47s and with the completion of the USAF installations in Spain in 1959.With the USAF withdrawal from Rabat-Salé in the 1960s, the facility became a primary facility for the Royal Moroccan Air Force known as Air Base Nº 1, a status it continues to hold.


== Geography ==


=== Neighbourhoods of Rabat ===
Rabat is an administrative city. It does have many shopping districts and residential neighbourhoods. The geographically spread out neighbourhoods are as follows:
The heart of the city consists of three parts: the Medina (old town); the Oudayas and Hassan both located to meet the Bou Regreg; and the Atlantic Ocean.
To the west, and along the waterfront, there is a succession of neighbourhoods.
First, around the ramparts, there is the old neighbourhoods, Quartier l'Océan and Quartier les Orangers. Beyond that, a succession of mostly working-class districts: Diour Jamaa, Akkari, Yacoub El Mansour, Massira and Hay el Fath are the main parts of this axis. Hay el Fath, which ends this sequence, evolves into a middle-class neighbourhood.
To the east, along the Bouregreg, the Youssoufia region (working and middle class) : Mabella; Taqaddoum; Hay Nahda(mostly middle class); Aviation(middle and upper middle class); and Rommani.
Between the two axes, from north to south, there are three main neighbourhoods (middle class to affluent): Agdal (Ward Building; a lively mix of residential and commercial buildings. The residents are predominantly upper middle class); Hay Riad (affluent villas; this neighbourhood has experienced a surge of momentum since the 2000s); and Souissi (residential neighborhood).
On the outskirts of Souissi, are a number of less-dense regions mainly comprising large private houses to areas that seem out of the city.

		
		
		
		


=== Bouregreg Marina ===
Located between the Atlantic and the Bouregreg Valley, this river marina is paved with famous historical sites like the esplanade of the Hassan Tower and the picturesque Chellah necropolis, which has witnessed many Mediterranean civilizations pass by.
Outfitted with the most modern equipment to host up to 240 boats, the Bouregreg Marina aims to become an essential destination for recreational boaters seeking long stays or just a stopover on their way to West Africa, the Caribbean or the shores of North America.

		


=== Subdivisions ===
The prefecture is divided administratively into the following:


=== Families of Rabat ===
Called Rbatis, these families have lived for more than 400 years with many events in common. From the expulsion of the Moriscos to arrive at the foundation of a culture that combines the Arabic and Andalusian cultures, through the Republic of Bouregreg events than other families coming to live in Rabat recently, have not known.
Since its founding, Rabat was inhabited by several families from the High Atlas with Abu Yusuf Yaqub al-Mansur, who founded the city in 1198, then families from many parts of Morocco have settled. Rabat has around 1240 a few hundred fifty families whose families Chiadmi, Regragui, Loudiyi, etc.
Since the end of the thirteenth century, the city has had an influx of Moriscos expelled from Granada until 1609, the year of total expulsion of Muslims from Spain by Philip III. These families include: Bargach (Vargas); Guedira (Guadaira); Mouline (Molina); Sebbata (Zapata); and Frej.
The said families are considered, until today, as "Rbati's Families of strain". They are about four hundred families.
Other families in the city are considered residents of Rabat because they came at the time when Rabat became the capital of the country, either through rural exodus or to work in public administration based in the city since the establishment of the protectorate.
The city is on the territory of Zaer, an Arab tribe of Maqil origin. Leo Africanus in the early 16th century the signals in the region of Khenifra there, she continued on to the north to the Rabat region.


=== Climate ===
Rabat features a Mediterranean climate (Csa) with warm to hot dry summers and mild damp winters. Located along the Atlantic Ocean, Rabat has a mild, temperate climate, shifting from cool in winter to warm days in the summer months. The nights are always cool (or cold in winter, it can reach sub 0 °C (32 °F) sometimes), with daytime temperatures generally rising about 7–8 °C (13–14 °F). The winter highs typically reach only 17.2 °C (63.0 °F) in December–February. Summer daytime highs usually hover around 25 °C (77.0 °F), but may occasionally exceed 30 °C (86.0 °F), especially during heat waves. Summer nights are usually pleasant and cool, ranging between 11 °C (51.8 °F) and 19 °C (66.2 °F) and rarely exceeding 20 °C (68.0 °F). Rabat belongs to the sub-humid bioclimatic zone with an average annual precipitation of 560 mm (22 in).


== Culture ==

The biggest place for theatre is the Theatre Mohammed V in the centre of the town.
The city has the Rabat Archaeological Museum and the Musée Mohamed VI d'Art Moderne et Contemporain.
Many organizations are active in cultural and social issues. Orient-Occident Foundation and ONA Foundation are the biggest of these. An independent art scene is active in the city. L'appartement 22, which is the first independent space for visual arts created by Abdellah Karroum, opened in 2002 and introduced international and local artists. Other independent spaces opened few years after, such as Le Cube, also set up in a private space.


=== Mawazine ===

Mawazine is a music festival in Rabat welcomed by Mohammed VI King of Morocco, that started in 2001 where music groups, fans and spectators come together in a week-long celebration of culture and music both locally and internationally. Musicians such as Scorpions, Rihanna, Elton John, Stromae and many others have performed at the festival.
Mawazine was host to more than 2,500,000 in 2013. Workshops are available for teaching dances and other arts. The festival is free. However, while most areas are free, there are those that require payment, specifically the smaller stages being the historical site of Chellah, the Mohammed V National Theater, and the Renaissance Cultural Center.


=== Places of worship ===

		
The places of worship are predominantly Muslim mosques. The last remaining synagogue in Rabat is the Rabbi Shalom Zawi Synagogue. There are also Christian churches and temples, including an Evangelical church and St. Peter's Cathedral, which hosts the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Rabat.


== Education ==
The Mohammed V University was founded in 1957.

== Transport ==


=== Air ===
Rabat's main airport is Rabat–Salé Airport.


=== Trains ===

Rabat is served by two principal railway stations run by the national rail service, the ONCF.
Rabat-Ville is the main inter-city station, from which trains run south to Casablanca, Marrakech and El Jadida, north to Tanger, or east to Meknes, Fes, Taza and Oujda.
ONCF operates the Le Bouregreg urban rail for Rabat-Salé agglomeration.


=== Tram ===

The Rabat-Salé tramway is a tram system which was put into service on May 23, 2011 in the Moroccan cities of Rabat and Salé. The network has two lines for a total length of 19 km (12 miles) and 31 stops. It is operated by Veolia Transdev with Alstom Citadis trams.


=== Public transport ===
After some years of neglect as investment was directed at the tramway,  the existing operator, STAREO, was displaced in 2019.  A contract was awarded to Alsa-City Bus, a joint venture between Moroccan company City Bus and Spanish company Alsa s.a, a subsidiary of the UK's National Express Group.   The new operator took over in July 2019 with a commitment to three hundred and fifty new buses. These will comprise 102 Mercedes-Benz and 248 Scania-Higer vehicles.  The contract covers a 15-year period, renewable for seven years, and promises approximately 10 billion dinars investment into the bus transport system in the region. 


== Sports ==
Prince Moulay Abdellah Stadium (Arabic: مركب الأمير مولاي عبد لله) is a multi-purpose stadium in Rabat, Morocco. It is named after Prince Moulay Abdellah. It was built in 1983 and is the home ground of ASFAR (football club). It is used mostly for football matches, and it can also stage athletics. The stadium holds 52,000. Since 2008 it is host of the Meeting International Mohammed VI d'Athlétisme de Rabat.
Rabat will host the 2019 African Games after Malabo, Equatorial Guinea stripped out of hosting due to economical matters. It will be the first time in an African Games to be hosted by Morocco.

This is a beautiful medina that is clean and interesting. This area is well worth a visit if you're in Rabat.

Enjoyed the stroll through Kasbah Oudaias a lot. Many jewels await around a corner, nice place to linger and take photos.

We arrived at this wonderful place around 5 pm, there were mainly local inhabitants and visitors walking around. No crowd no hustle and bustle at all. The view of the Atlantic was stunning! The colour blue is present everywhere and the small and narrow alleys are so picturesque.
A truly amazing experience, wandering through these narrow, cobbled streets should be everyone travellers bucket list. Simple as that.

The Kasbah des Oudaias is a charming walled place with old houses and narrow cobbled streets. All the houses are painted in white with blue shades. One side is lying on the Atlantic Ocean. There is also a garden called Andalusian Gardens. The garden is full of trees and flowers.

We got an impromptu tour from the security guard! Turned out that inside there's a whole neighborhood that's like a separate little town on its own. Wonderful place for great views up on top. Go check it out!
Have tea in the corner bar, mix with the locals and have the best view from the Kasbah as a defender of Rabat would have !
It's a fun area to explore with the signature blue buildings and winding alleys. Be careful of hawkers though. One lady invited us into her house and we ended up having to pay her.

The Oudaias Kasbah is a neighborhood that is a must see. As you enter through a massive ornate gate, you feel like you are in another world with the stunning blue and white homes and shops. This sight is reminiscent of Chefchaouen in its color scheme.
Dropping by for photo is ok. An intended visit is not worthwhile. The view is not so grand. No special nor unique.
We met a young man who gave us a tour - about an hour. We gave him 150 dirham. Worth every single minute.

A Kasbah neighborhood is a must see and Rabat has a stunning one. You enter through a massive ornate gate and you feel like you are in another planet with the stunning blue and white homes and shops. Also look at the gardens. There are also beautiful views of the Atlantic.

What a beautiful spot in Rabat to spend a few hours wandering about. Safe and friendly and very pretty. Loads of photo opportunities and cats.... did I mention CATS... I really enjoyed the gardens too.

Super charming maze of blue painted streets, cool doors, and decor. This is a residential area and home to artists. Stopping at Cafe Maure for some mint tea before departing is a great way to spend the afternoon. Highly recommended!

Beautiful exhibit of the Rabat, Morocco biennale as well as the historical new site. The kasbah was nicely restored and the gardens are a haven for peace and tranquility. It is now my favorite place in Rabat

This is a lovely cute area with a small museum of photographs and lots of cats in the gardens. Small shops to buy souvenirs and a great cafe that juts out to the sea (go right to the back of this cafe through the little lane where their is a small seating area.) There is a man
this is the place you have to visit whenever you are in rabat , the real spirit of the ancient medima and it small ruelles all in blu
This was a pretty good experience, even down to the seedy looking fellow saying “it is not safe to go down there”. Wonderful location too. Must see if visiting Rabat.

Kasbahs can be seen everywhere in Morocco. They are fortresses, or better, fortified settlements. The one in Rabat is a beautifu, well-preserved building and it offers nice views of the city. There is a cafe where you can have nice mint tea and very good cookies. People selling

Went to Kasbah de Oudaias (also known as the Fortress of Ouddayas) for a quick visit whilst passing through Rabat. I would have liked to spend a couple of hours longer there as it was a very interesting and picturesque place. Well worth the visit.

Really enjoyed the Rabat Kasbah - you can have a coffee and local sweets looking over the fortified wall onto the Sale river, while watching people bathing and kids jumping into the water - the interior gardens, walls, and adjoining old town, a mini Chefchaouen, are all
Take your time, have a tea, enjoy the sweets. Great view on the nearby beach. Once refueled go and visit the medina, even if you get lost it will be a good moment.

Lovely gardens with a very pleasant guide. Interesting variety of plants in the garden and lovely views of towers with the storks nest and pool with eels which unfortunately did not come out to play.

In spite of the many visitors, you can get around. This is a must see. The views are great from several areas. Try not to get lost. Great picture old.

An originally cool Kasbah to walk and picture alto capture the experience of the classical area Very cool photo opportunity
This kasbah my the sea has a true Mediterranean feel. Wind your way through the streets to the vast plaza that overlooks the Atlantic
Beautiful blue walls. GREAT view of the beach, cityand surfers. Would recommend nothing more than a few hours but well worth a visit.

Our tour group stopped here. We walked around the alleyways, viewed the Atlantic Ocean for great photos. Shop owners were friendly and welcoming. Lots of cats around...some look fed, others not so much. Recent excavation to the left as you walk in the main gate.

A must place to visit when in Rabat. Beautiful view of the atlantic ocean. You can experience life of people living there, walking around small streets and buy nice souvenirs. Very pleasant place, streets are clean and full of tourists

Something to see if you have some time spare in Rabat. I would suggest Chellah as the best fortified site to visit, the area is not very big and there is not much to visit. Rabat has a lot more to offer
Just what I expected, little winding cobble streets, tiny tavernas and small shops to buy morrocon pottery and decorative items, beautiful.

The Kasbah does have a lot to see, with not a lot to do. It will certainly take a good hour if you cover every part with a slow amble, but the views are stunning & the winding streets are encapsulating. Somewhere you shouldn’t miss, & also a cat lovers dream!
Beautiful panoramic view of the ocean, a must visit when in Rabat. We really enjoyed the views from above!
For Rabat expiriances this tops the list. You simply can’t go to Rabat without a stop here. And it’s a mere minutes from the market
This is the place to visit if you have no time to visit Chefchaouen. This blue and white village definitely makes it worth to visit! Also the sea view!

Beautiful gardens. Beautiful streets of blue walls. If your going to sit down, be sure to be prepared to buy a tea or sweet.

really nice to walk around. We were guided around by one of the young boys offering to do so. It was a god idea as it is quit a labyrinth. Be sure to agree upon a price first as he made a whole scene when I found €5 enough for a 25 minutes tour. Even in Holland that is a good

I was glad to make a stop here, first building in Rabat overseeing the Bou Regreg river and Atlantic ocean. It was nice to take a walk here and see the blue and white walls with its narrows streets.

Walked around the Kasbah streets, found everyone really friendly, no pressure to buy from shops. Great architecture up to the view across the river entrance and beaches. Well worth the walk.

An interesting Rabbit Warren of signature white and blue houses. At the end you get a good look at the river mouth and the 2 main beaches. No charge to enter and hassle free once inside the wall.

This area is great for walking. Excellent views over river and Atlantic Ocean Narrow lanes with blue and white lime wall colours Ensure you stop at Cafe Maure for mint tea and delicious selection of Morrocan cakes The Andulasian Gardens are also beautiful

This is a historic kasbah. It is quite striking with blue and white walls and stylish doors. There are many cats. The Andalusian gardens are a very pleasant open garden area.
blue dwellings in Kasbah with small alleys, and it's local residential area. At times I felt intruding the locals' privacy while wandering around, but the area is just picturesque

One of the oldest citadels in Morocco it overlooks the Atlantic ocean and the river's mouth. Blue and white buildings with the Andalusian Garden.

I was thinking about this song. Rock the Kasbah and how interesting this country is . It very different country and it a great destination for one bucket list. I highly recommend going to Morocco and visiting the sight and taste the food.

Good to walk around, but not friendly place for stroller of our infant grand daughter.The view of sea is excellent

It's a nice view from up there overlooking Sale and the river. The souk and medina is right next to it and there's the beach just behind. There's little area with blue houses similar to Chefchaouen if you don't get to visit Chefchaouen. It's free to walk around inc the Andalucia

The Kasbah is a nice location for a slow walk along the paths, streets, to appreciate the gardens, views, shops, architecture, and save time to enjoy a tea and pastry with a nice view of the river. It's pretty inside and one of the nicer kasbah's we saw on our 10 day adventure.
This was nice and so so traditional.you can see the Andulous garden inside there.you should drink mint tea across the ocean view.Windy weather was so nice

Get inside and walk. Just walk and admire all the beauty. It is one of the top 5 of all my trips. Join it.
Love the small alleys with blue and white colors, and the view to Rabat from the top. You can drink the mint tea and cookies while enjoying the view

Intriguing alleys and interesting stroll that leads you to the top with panoramic views of the beach and Atlantic Ocean. Vendors align the street with their trade but all the more important part is its richness in history. One of the many sights and sounds in Rabat not to be

We stayed at a riad in the casbah so walked through it a lot. It's picturesque and charming with the beautiful Andalusian Gardens attached. Worth the visit.
Very nice to wander around here without any plan. Many streets, doors and windows are very nicely decorated. The Andalusian Gardens are worth a visit aswell.
Vestiges of old Rabat, quite lovely to walk around, a bit too touristy. You can walk there from the old medina / market area.

Great to wander the streets, very beautiful scenes everywhere, felt quite safe and lots of chances to take good photos. The view out over the Atlantic was amazing. Be nice to spend some time here and not be in a rush. There is much to enjoy.
Beautiful gardens and architecture. The vendors are not at all pushy. Overall a wonderful experience.

We were surprised that with so many buildings and laneways how quiet and clean it was. The buildings are really interesting and the ocean views were lovely. We only had an hour or so there but really liked what we saw and would have liked to have spent at least a day or so
The famous blue and white walls and decorated doors do not disappoint. Take your time to just wander through, and be sure to visit the terrace for a lovely view of the sea.

Walking through the narrow white and blue streets filled with beautiful doors and the typical Fatima Hand was very enjoyable in itself. The views from the top to the ocean are striking. Parts of the kasbah are preserved and definitely worth visiting. A delightful couple of hours

Part of it has been restored to allow visitors to enjoy this place. overall it left a good impression.
I was amazed by the view from the kasbah. Its a historical site overlooking the sea. Must visit site in rabat. Perfect place to take in the view.

I loved the doors . While you walk through the neighborhood you will see white and blue houses. It’s a picturesque neighborhood, you will love take a picture in that area. If you see a street in white, it means it’s a dead end.

We're the highlight of this visit to the Kasbah. It has a nice garden and walk up to the hill through this nice blue and white narrow lanes. On top there is an open view area giving the nice view of Rabat-sale area and the coastline. It is also worth going around using small

You will probably want to bring a camera to capture images of the very interesting homes in the a residential neighborhood, particularly its distinct blue and white walls. The variation in design, construction and decoration of the house doors offers another possible
Both the walk imside the medina is interesting as you experience Moroccan culture. It is also a short walk away from the beach and sweeping views of the harbour.
There are some steps and uneven pavement to deal with walking around this Kasbah, but worth seeing. Beautiful views.

We walked in this little Medina looked like place. It has a very nice terrace on the top where you can admire the ocean. Very peaceful. Definitely a must seen place in rabat. The coffee is nice where you can sit and drink mint tea and eat Moroccon sweets.

We toured only a small part of the Kasbah and saw very old residences (all painted white and blue), tight lanes, cafes overlooking the river and Sale and a beautiful French garden. We spent only 20 minutes in the Kasbah, though our tour guide told us the rest of the larger area

This old site where Rabat was first established. The outside walls are picturesque. Not much to see inside. Only a short visit for some photos.
Nice place where you can see how rabat was foundes. Small streets with the traditional houses. You dont need a guideman , despite several will offer you their services.

It's lovely walking through the little streets. The views are beautiful from the top and the mosque is old and quaint.

We were there with our tour guide and il was worth seing. It is a whole street of beautiful buildings. I suggest you visit it if you are in Rabat.

amazing place and careful, just stay away from the boys who will offer u a tour, u can walk around by ur self.

A beautiful part of Rabat - little Greece in Morocco. Lovely blue and white buildings and great views of the ocean. Pleasant cafes and lots of people watching opportunities.
For this you have to walk through the narrow street to get the view. You see various old styled doors on the way.

This was really my favourite spot in Rabat with its narrow streets and beautifully painted houses, but for me the best thing was the view of the sea, and the architecture of the stairways leading down

The Kasbah is located where the river meets the sea. You can look back at the city, or you can look down on the beach. The day I visited, there was mist along the shore, which made the fort appear a bit mysterious. There are homes on the hill inside the walls of the fortress,

Nice Kasbah, and with a little tip you can also have a guide that explains you about the buildings, people that used to live, the origin of the city, etc. Once you got in, you can walk between the tiny streets and houses painted in white and blue, that stand for peace and ocean,

We enjoyed this visit. The little streets inside the Kasbah with the white and blue paint are very interesting. You need to walk to the very end so you can get out to the open area to overlook parts of Rabat and the ocean. Easy to get to and you do not need to have a tour guide

We entered the Kasbah the rough it's newly renovated gate area. Here- like in Chefchaouen the buildings are painted blue and white. Some say it is because the pirate ships were painted blue they used the remaining paint to paint houses, others say it is some remains of religion
Narrow alleyways, blue walls , interesting perspecitves, but the artisan work was lacking both quality and quantity.

Here you will find a clean and peaceful zone which is a nice getaway from the Medina if you happen to be staying there. Some of the alleyways resemble Greece, and there is a nice place for tea and pastry with a view.

The view of the Ocean is wonderful as are the cooling breezes. the small alley's lead you to a beautiful garden. We took many photos of the greenery, walls of the Kasbah, and the locals themselves. Lots of cats and people relaxing.
Perfect spot :) It is a town in a capital, so nice and with amazing views ;) From top you can see both Sale and Rabat

Great to explore around, notice the small streets and blue painted walls. Continue through to have a view of the sea. Continue down to a charming terrace for tea and pastries overlooking the water. Don't fall for the trick to need a 'guide' or that they'll point you in

Beautiful garden, beautiful sea view, beautiful architecture. I would definitely visit again if I travel to Morocco next time!

I was transported to a completely different land when I visited this kasbah. We got a local tour guide who took us around and explained the history. The doors were beautifully designed and decorated. The Sea view was beautiful.

It is definitely a place to be seen in Rabat. A beautiful kasbah in the citadel. When you go up the hill from Chefchaouen-like narrow blue streets, you will have a wonderful view of the ocean. You can buy something from the small bazaar inside the town. It is delightful to sit
do go to this place, very different than europe. You can feel the atmosphere of the place and get strange things to eat.

I fell for the Kasbah Oudaisas. The old wall, the gates, the intricate plaster work around the gates, the narrow winding alleys, painted half blue. One felt one was back in time. The super clean alleys were impressive. It was early morning so it was not busy at all. If we

Take a guide at the entrance 10 euro Very nice street in side look very similar to Chefchaouen all the houses are colored white and blue the view from edge to the ocean is very nice

our very first stop after Casablanca and the huge rather overblown mosque of Hassan II was this lovely site undergoing conservation. full of charm and picturesque little passageways, the village contained within is home to locals and some galleries and small shops. a quick

Kasbah des Outdaias we visited on our peregrine tour of Rabat. It is definitely an older part of Rabat. I liked the old clay buildings painted in white and blue colours. I loved the view of the coast. I'm assuming it is similar to Greek Islands. Hints: good footwear, suitable

This is a kasbah where locals still reside. Stroll the narrow passages and see an ancient bakery with a huge oven fueled by hand with wood chips, a musician playing folk tunes on his gimbri, a beautiful garden, and views of the ocean. Relax for a bit with tea, fruit juices, and
They had a beautiful resting area to have mint tea and local pastries facing the ocean. The gardens have exoctic flowers.

Kasbah des Oudaias is a district with old clay buildings painted in white and blue colors like on the Cyclades in Greece. From the top you can see Rabat beach and seaside. Fun place to walk in the narrow streets.

Fascinating history here. And beautiful views of the water. Our visit was marred by a persisitent henna tattoo artist named Sarah who did more than we requested and over charged us. It was a waste of too much money.
Many of the homes have a blue wash, so the effect is picturesque. The inner gardens and artefacts are lovely.
We have lost our phone in the market which was a shock because we have the phone in our hands. Just be more careful when you travel to here but all the rest is very nice

What a nice place to visit and see the winding roads and nice blue-painted walls of the Kasbah. Our guide told us that the front steps of this Kasbah was a scene in one of the Mission Impossible movies where Tom Cruise drove a motorcycle down the steps. Our tour group of 35

This part of the city is very special for its colours and sea view. If you stroll down the hill, you can also have lunch, since inside the kasbah area there are no such facilities. Ignore the locals, they only care for your money. Don't talk at them at all.

This is a place not to miss. Take a walk slowly and stop and cvhat with local people. All is bvright in white and azul, full of light, climbing not very tiring upto the terrace with a view on the corniche and on the river. Along the climb a colourful bazar with a coffee shop
This is one of my favourite spots in Rabat as it provides a unique atmosphere of peacefulness and beautiful sceneries. The gardens are well maintained and the nearby shops are good.

This is a gorgeous place. Narrow blue and white streets that lead to an ocean view. The houses are so quaint with their terraces and clothes drying. Definitely climb all the way to the top. It closes at a certain time but if you pay the person they will let you through. The view
breakfast serve at 9 am,authintic moroccan serve, peaceful,relaxing,enjoying the view with rm to be occupied to rest....souvienrs n morocains sweets are there to buy...ppl are so warm.

Upon entering we were followed by a local man who led us around the Kasbah. He was well informed and gave a good insight into the fortress but these details could be taken from the internet or guide book without the hefty charge the supposed residents can seek for the privilege!

Some nice art shops, small contained area. Mostly closed on Fridays. Worth a short wander perhaps. Construction work in progress.
Do not forget to check this place when you visit Rabat. A trip to the Oudaiya is a must! Remember to avoid the local tour guides, try to sightseeing on your own :)

The Kasbah is beautiful and full of life and history. The interior garden is a great place to lounge, take tea or read a novel. There is an adjacent cafe overlooking the Oued Bourereg (river) where you can imagine corsair ships being docked. Great for a Sunday walk, a history
Awesome area to check out! I really enjoyed walking around the area. Just beware of very aggressive vendors, especially with henna. They'll "attack" with the henna and make you pay for it.
Right in the center og town. Open to the public and under restoration. You must have Moroccan mint tea, while enjoying the scenic sea view.
Full disclosure: we visited this in pouring rain, which may have dampened (literally) our enthusiasm. Nice to view from the outside (walls, cannon), but once you're inside, pretty ho-hum.

Beware of pop-up tour guides that try to take you on tours and expect a tip. You can easily walk and navigate the streets yourself. Very photogenic, but tiny streets are a little stinky (think cat pee/poo) and it's easy to get lost. Worth the trip for the photos alone and the

This place has magnificent and beautiful views. It's great to have a long walk and visit the locals in this kasbah and it's ruins. Beautiful.! Just grab a fresh orange squeeze or pomegranate juice along the way while walking all the way up for a view of the sea. Stupendo.!

Strategic position guarding the point where the river meets the Atlantic,with fabulous views and vistas out to sea and across to Sale.Lovely Andalusian garden you can spend time in too.Some nice little cafes and scenic pedestrian streets,well worth visiting.Ordinary Moroccans

If you get the opportunity to stop over in Rabat, a trip to the Oudaiya is a must! A beautiful small neighborhood painted in blue, the Oudaiya is the perfect place to get lost exploring. Come at sunset, and be sure to stop over at the small cafe overlooking the river outlet. the

The Kasbah is a small area in the old town of Rabat. The house are painted with blue and white, which is making the charm of the place. Not so fancy as Chefchaouen, you might still find some beautiful spots for those blue streets photos. The area is rather small, so don't get

Quirky, artisanal, walk. Artists at work in their studios. The view at the end is panoramic as you see the key, the ocean, and the river.

We visited this on a sunny January day expecting something picturesque and were disappointed. It all looked a bit run down and neglected. The views from the square overlooking the sea were nice but nothing special. There are a few shops in the main street, and nice that we were

If you are looking for a place when u can listen to youth singing and playing guitars, if you want to observe the people, play with kittens, and have a nice walk inside the Kasbah and explore the small streets painted in white and blue !
Kasbah small town decoration in blue color. Nice view from the coast walking nearby. Also a town of cats surroundings in place.

We enjoyed roaming the colorful alleyways filled with flowers and artistic doorways. There are many opportunities for pictures and for making small purchases such as the candies and coffees. We spent time in the garden and had an enjoyable hour or so.
Always beautiful, and a lovely view of BouRegreg. Walk down to the cornice after for a nice stroll and a coffee

The old Kasbah of Rabat had on the seaside also the function of fort, situated where the river Oued Bou Regreg meets the sea, it had a very strategic position. Do not hire a guide, the ask too much for too little information and try to lead you to their friends shpos. It is
Avoid the "tour guides" or at the very least negotiate the price at the start. I loved the andulucian gardens. The view from the kasbar out to see is also worth seeing.

I found this neighborhood after wandering through the medina, and was charmed by its blue and white scheme, narrow walkways, and ornate doorways. After a bit of walking, it pops out on a lovely ocean view. Worth a quick walk-through if you're nearby, especially near sunset.
The fortifications and the walk along the sea was beautiful. We stayed there, overlooking the view, for quite some time.
Apartments are on the high for room at this Andalusian fortification. Charming winding streets with a great ocean view cafes w/ sweet vendors & friendly kitties!

Unlike the medina, this old town is quiet and colourful, Do not expect much merchants but enjoy the walk and end up in the Cafe Maure for a mint tea and some pastries.

The oudayas are an enclosed a little town within a town. You can walk around the narrow cobble-stone paved streets. Beautiful tiny little doors sometimes grace the entrance of houses there. I had the opportunity to enter a couple and they typically all have an interior

Rabat, the capitol of Morocco, is the 7th largest city center hosting almost 600,000 people and adding the surrounding communities--2.1 million. Located on the Atlantic Ocean and by river Bou Regreg, the waves come crashing against the coast and against the light house. Kasbah

A nice place to relax and sit for a while, where you can smell the flowers and oranges in an Andalusian-style exotic garden. Lots of friendly cats. The outside walls are being renovated but it is still open to the public.

From the blue/white painting, the ocean overlooks, the Andalusian garden, and the great cemetery next door.... We only had a short time but we're impressed by what we were able to see. The area was overall smaller than expected and easy to get around. Nothing exceptional but
Beautiful view and very well maintained. Takes about one hour if you take your guide or 30 min to just walk around. They have tea shop which is is but with veery nice view.

A great way to spend a few hours with friends or families, with a museum and a park, a few arts & crafts boutiques, two tea house (slow, slow service). A nice destination to walk to from the Medina itself (10 minutes top), atmospheric but not flashy, authentic but not tacky.
Walking through here you get the feeling that you are really now in Morocco. There is much to see and it all adds up to a pleasant place to visit.

Behind the Medina of Rabat lays the Kasbah des Oudalas. This is the oldest part of Rabat. It gives a good idea how cities started. To understand the strategic location, you can walk down to a pier that protects the entrance of the harbor from the sea.

Small, narrow streets, some painted in deep blue with a nice view of the sea and the cemetery - visit the cemetery as well. However quirt a few unofficial guides were paddling their pretend services. Don't bother; just wonder around on your own pace.

This little enclave has a great view of the sea. The blue washed walls were interesting, though spoiled by the power line running through them. The fort was under repair while while we were visiting. The gardens were pleasant as well.
Very typical Kasbah, narrow streets, white and blue small buildings make you feel the past, small friendly shops and cafes and a short view of the port will complete the experience.

First stop was at a tiny store selling sfinge Moroccan doughnuts and next to it another one selling r’gaif flat bread (both very tasty). Next we stopped at Gnawa Moroccan troubadour and joined his singing. Arrived through the blue alleys to the beautiful lookout on the river

Walking around the twisty blue alleys, seeing the old buildings and how people live, it was just awesome. I would recommend spending sometime there looking down all the little streets. Watch out for the carts being pulled by donkeys down these little streets. Just a nice
You must visit that place! You can walk to see the nice architecture and the decoration of the houses.

We wandered around the casbah on our first morning in Rabat. A man approached us and kept giving us recommendations on where to turn. At the end, he insisted on a tip, and refused anything less than 50 MAD. Watch out for this.

The star is the Andalucian Garden (very popular with the local cat population). The el-Atiqa mosque (the oldest in Rabat) is worthy of a special mention. The walls of the kasbah allow good views across the river to Sale.

There was guy who rushed us away and we could not see the sunset. The place closed just after sunset which at the time of our visit was 18-30. We were there at 17:45 and the guy rushed us away saying that it is Friday and he wants to go home. This was quite rude. He was yelling
Ok, so you have to say you've been to the Kasbah. Some nice photo ops inside. But don't despair if you miss it.

Beautiful Kasbah, nice view of the ocean and the city of Sale. Beware of guides (they will tell you you need a guide to get in, it's not true, or that the kasbah closes in one hour for a holiday, it's not true). Just wandering around those beautiful streets is a good experience.

This castle is a must visit when in Rabat, but be aware of the local-guides who wants to show you arround and expect a fee. We told him that we didn't want a guide, but he told us that we wold get lost if we go by our self. I would recommend to just say: I have been here before,

Great place for a short visit. We were welcomed into the house of a very nice family living in the Kasbah and got a great taste of life in this quite calm part of Morocco. A pleasent change to the chaos of most souks and medina's in Morocco.

Externally it looks good but inside a bit sad although the views from the highest areas give you a sense of direction above the river entrance. Beware of the guys faking a tour...it's easy to find ones own way.

Nice place to walk around and visits in general. Nice blue buildings all over the Kasbah, nice views of the river and sea. I just think the cafe is a total rip off. 16MAD for a weird type of coffee is totally overpriced, the pastries are quite expensive as well.

Great views of the beaches of Rabat and cemetery of Rabat. In front of the fortress, before going in, take a look in the direction of the lighthouse, the scenery is incredible. Inside you can find some really nice houses and doors to take some pictures.

Good views of the twin cities of Rabat and Sale and of the Atlantic ocean. Houses are well preserved to reflect the ancient history.
We really enjoyed our visit to the Kasbah. It was rather hard walking on the cobblestones and uneven ground, but definitely worth the effort.

Easily the top attraction of the Moroccan capital, this medieval citadel is so picture-perfect that will surely drain your camera's battery so come prepared. The magnificent main gate will lead you to the panoramic terrace (offering commanding ocean vistas and memorable sunsets)

This Casbah is truly unique! One wants never to stop wondering through its labyrinths and picturesque allies. There are also wild beaches where cliffs allow you to jump into the river. It's hard to describe the feeling that gets you in this place... I just loved it!
Very pleasant walk through the narrow blue streets. All round beautiful place to wonder! There's also a street market right in front. It's a must see if you plan to stop in Rabat.
a nice winding and unwinding of ways in the kasbah, lovely rooftop view of the ocean, and nice garden walk/view before you exit the kasbah..

Kasbah of Oudaya has a "museum" to visit (which is in fact an old fighting palace - not a museum), a blue maze of roads where expelled Muslims and Jews settled after leaving Andalucia and last but definitely not least the famous café. The café offers a breathtaking panoramic
NIce place just to walk around the small white and blue houses and to enjoy the ocean view from the terrace.If you been in Chefchaouen that is small version ;) Good point to take some picture
We enjoyed the old places in Rabat including this.. It will help take a glimpse of what you can see in the other city in Morocco..

Beautiful place just to walk around the small white houses and to enjoy the ocean view from the terrace. Be careful of the fake guides! And enjoy a walk in the Oudaya garden and a tea at Café Maure, a must!
A place you need to visit in Rabat Have a cup of moroccan Mint tea and enjoy the view on the Bouregreg river and the Ocean

Interesting living city inside a site oozing history, and fantastic views of the river and the ocean from the platform. Pestering 'guides' providing unsolicited guidance, and not willing to leave you alone until offer a tip.
The Blue and White Colour makes it different from other Morocco Medinas. The Cafe Oudaya is the best spot to sit and view the Atlantic after exploring the entire Medina

Nice place which reminded me about Greece. I wonder why there were not more coffee shops, it was very hot and we spend some time to find one. More signs would be good, because we walked almost around the place before we found Cafe and water.

There is certainly a charm regarding the place when walking through the narrow winding streets and exploring this community with its unique white and blue walls. Some places offer tea and there are markets and small gardens you can walk through.
Nice place however the gardens are not well maintained. A good view over the estuary of Rabat in the tea corner
It's a touristic place with a real flare of peaceful and interesting architecture. One must stop at the Berber Cafe overlooking the Bouregreg river seeping mint tea and Moroccan sweet pastries.

After a walk through the kasbah spend some time on the sea side and enjoy the view. Good spot for photos. The best time to visit the kasbah is morning. Visit the gallery on main street and the panoramic cafe on the top of the wall.
You will discover place where river meets ocean. That can not be expressed through words. You should visit and see it with your own eyes!
Be sure to walk up through the narrow streets toward the sea. Many of these houses are blue and white. There are very nice views awaiting you at the end.

i would recommend this place if ur in Rabat. It's on a cliff edge and very picturesque housing with narrow winding roads amazing Moroccan doors! It's very small so won't take long to look around and then there is a rocky beach at the bottom or Sale plage opposite which is dirty

Very beautiful streets in blue and white, a café with a great view on the Bouregreg River where you can drink a good Moroccan mint tea and delicious Moroccan pastries

This is a small fortified town with gorgeous white houses, blue doors and windows, narrow streets. From huge terrace is a great view over Atlantic. In small caffe we enjoy Moroccan mint tea and good biscuits.
Very pretty little area with a great view of the water. I probably would have gotten more out of it if the museums were open to provide a little more history and background.

Take the time to wander through this historic and picturesque kasbah in the city of Rabat. It is a charming example, with lovely buildings, and a dsitinctly medditerainean feel with the gorgeous blue and while colours throughout.

Such a beautiful place, even slightly reminiscent of Santorini with its blue and white colour schemes of the houses. However beauty can come with a price as we were pestered by some locals who at some point wouldn't leave us alone and even intimidated us. We saw a previous

If you are in Morocco.make sure you visit this place.. very beautiful. Inside the ford is small beautiful ancient blue city. Outside is spectacular sea view. I feel like i am in Game of Thrones movie..

The walls to the casbah are interesting (btw part of the latest Mission Impossible was filmed on the steps outside), but inside there are lots of surprises. The streets are very pretty, picturesque, and worth exploring. At the far corner there is a fantastic view of the coast

The colours of the Kasbah are great; white and blue, similar to that of other Mediterranean locales. There is a garden within the kasbah, as well as a good lookout over the beach. The kasbah was a highlight of our stop in Rabat.
Have a stroll and get into the local feeling of this marvel of tourism. Get into the coffee scene - just great
A lovely place to visit and can spend as long as you like there. The roof top terrace is a lovely place to have a mint tea.
If you want to admire the Atlantic ocean, there's no better place to see it from in Rabat, you don't need a guide, ignore the youngsters telling you it's going to close in an hour.

The old walled city is peaceful and pretty with its blue and white buildings. The area is well maintained and clean. We weren't hassled at all and it wasn't a high traffic area when we were there. Once at the highest point the view is very good.
this is the real Marocco, simple and clean thats what you get. A nice pool and friendly poeple. Staff is very helpful. I will be back to this nice place. The beach is amazing. Sunset breathless.

The Kasbah is the oldest part of Rabat. Goging trough the large 12th century gate (Bab Kebir = big gate) you enter a part of the town with beautiful wite and blue houses. Just continue to walk uphill until you reach te big terrace that gives a great view over the ocean and Salé.

This incredibly beautiful part of the city was overrun by false guides who prey on visitors and try to trick them into hiring them. My two visits were made so unpleasant, I was forced to walk away. A great shame.
Great easy walk with incredible views no guide needed. Don't mis the tranquil gardens in the Kasbah. A real gem
It's a nice place in Rabat, peaceful environment, visit the garden, the café by the beach and DON'T forget to go upstairs and check the view from the top.

Nice gardens and nice walk to the terraces overlooking the ocean. Be careful of people directing you into the side streets and offering to help you find your way. Stay on the main road and you won't have a problem.

An interesting and complex Kasbah. Beautiful streets with interesting buildings. The garden is beautiful. Be aware of touts who offer to guide you thru the Kasbah. They will take you off the main walks and then of course require payment for their services.
If you cannot visit Chef then this is perfect. it has small blue white narrow streetd.. perfect for a short walk.. don't miss it!
Mud on the outside, beautiful blue and white alley ways open up before you when you enter. Lovely place to stroll around, maybe do a little light shopping and enjoy and glass of mint tea

beautiful blue and white town hidden inside, a short walk from the beach, which is beautiful from atop!

text.wiki:
The Chellah or Shalla (Berber languages: Sla or Calla; Arabic: شالة‎), is a medieval fortified Muslim necropolis located in the metro area of Rabat, Morocco, on the south (left) side of the Bou Regreg estuary. The Phoenicians established a trading emporium at the site. This was later the site of an ancient Roman colony in the province of Mauretania Tingitana.
Salā was the name given to the city founded by the Muslim conquerors of North Africa, which was mostly abandoned during the Almohad era, then rebuilt by the Marinids in the 13th century. The  ruins of their medieval fortress are still extant.
The Berber Almohads used the site as a royal burial ground. The Marinids made the site a holy necropolis, or chellah, and built a complex that included mosque, minaret, and royal tombs. The tall minaret of the now-ruined mosque was built of stone and zellige tilework, and still stands.
Contrary to legend, the corsairs of Salé did not actually operate out of Salé (called "Old Salé"), but out of the city that would later become known as Rabat, ("New Salé") on the south (left) bank of the Bou Regreg.


== History ==


=== Phoenician Sala ===
The Phoenicians founded several trading colonies in what is now Morocco. The settlement along the banks of the Bou Regreg was known as Shalat (Punic: 𐤔𐤏‬𐤋𐤕, šʿlt). It was later controlled from Carthage.


=== Roman Sala Colonia ===
The Romans later built their own city, Sala Colonia, very near the same site. The Roman town was referred to as "Sala" by Ptolemy.
Excavations show a substantial port city with ruined Roman architectural elements including a decumanus maximus or principal roadway, a forum and a triumphal arch. Sala was a center of Christianity from the 2nd century.

One of the two main Roman Roads in Mauretania Tingitana reached the Atlantic through Iulia Constantia Zilil (Asilah), Lixus (Larache) and Sala Colonia. Another may have been built towards the south, from Sala to modern Casablanca, then called Anfa. The Romans had two main naval outposts on the Atlantic coast of the province: Sala Colonia, and Lixus. The port of Sala (now disappeared) was used by commercial Roman ships as a way station on their southwestward passages to Anfa and the Insula Purpuraria (Mogador island).Sala remained linked to the Roman Empire even after the withdrawal in the 4th century of the occupying Roman legions to Tingis and Septem in northern Mauretania Tingitana. A Roman military unit remained there until the end of the 5th century. Archaeological objects of Visigothic and Byzantine origin found in the area attest to the persistence of commercial or political contacts between Sala and Roman Europe, up to the establishment of a Byzantine presence in Berber North Africa during the 7th century.


=== Muslim Salā ===

Sala continued to exist as a town of the Christianized Berbers, but was mostly in ruins when the Muslim Arabs arrived in the 7th century. The Byzantine governor of the area, Count Julian of Ceuta, surrendered to Uqba ibn Nafi in 683. Around 1030, the town of Salā was founded at the site by the Banu 'Ashara family. With the extinction of the Umayyad dynasty in 1031, the Almoravids assumed control of the Maghreb (present-day Tunisia, Algeria, Morocco) and erected new buildings in Salā. They rebuilt the Great Mosque of Salā on the site of the mosque of the Banu 'Ashara, completing it in 1196.By 1147, the Almoravids had been overthrown by the Berber Almohads, who used the site as a royal burial ground. It was made a sacred necropolis, or chellah, by the Marinids in the 13th century; the Muslim sanctuary complex of mosque, minaret, and royal tombs being built by Abu Yusuf Yaqub, and finished in 1284. His remains were moved to the necropolis after he died at Algeciras in 1286. The tall minaret of the now-ruined mosque was built of stone and zellige tilework, and still stands.  Near the minaret is the tomb of the Maranid ruler, Abu al-Hasan Ali ibn Othman, known as the Black Sultan.
Many of the remaining structures in Chellah were damaged by the 1755 Lisbon earthquake.  The site has been converted to a garden and tourist venue, and today it is included in the metropolitan area of Rabat.


== Music Venue ==
Since 2005, the ruins of Chella host an international "Festival of Jazz" each year, called Jazz au Chellah. Additionally, it is currently home to a venue of the annual Mawazine music festival in Rabat, usually showcasing jazz or traditional music, as opposed to more popular contemporary music featured at some of the larger venues.


== World Heritage Status ==
The site, as part of the metropolitan Rabat, was granted World Heritage Status in 2012.


== See also ==

Colonia (Roman)
Exploration of Africa
Mauretania Tingitana
Roman roads in Morocco
Volubilis


== Gallery ==

		
		
		


== References ==

(in French)

text.quote: Landscaped gardens on the site of an ancient citadel featuring Roman ruins & royal tombstones.
trip: At the exiting from Rabat to the north, en route to Shipshawan, is worth stopping on the way at La Forum, or by the other name Chellah. The place is a historical site from the Roman period. On a warm day not so pleasant there but overall the place is lovely. The Chassidic nests

Best to see with a local guide who will explain the history of the locations and its sites within. Probably 1- 11/2 hour needed to see this lovely ruin and garden. Rabat is a clean modern town and is a pleasure to stay within.

The Chellah was my biggest surprise in Rabat. Not only was the entrance and courtyard dramatic against the skyline but the ruined Roman town inside was a wonderful sight as well as a beautiful place to linger and take in the peace of this haven within the city of Rabat.
Worth a visit to this ruins. It is not very far from the centre but need to get a taxi to there. I spend 1-1/2 hr in the ruins
Went to these ruins 10 years ago really enjoyed the tour guide who took me there to explain everything.

Very nice gardens with ruins of the former Roman city. 70 Dhiram to get in. Lots of renovation work going on at the moment so not at its best right now. Seemed a little overpriced. I knew there would be a lot of stray cats there so I bought a (2kg! - it was on special offer in
I highly recommend you visit , it's a nice place to relax and walk a bit, some great roman history is found there ,do the tour yourself .
This is a beautiful old Roman city that is worth visiting if you're in Rabat. I loved seeing the nesting storks as well.

I have seen many tourist turn their back at the entrance because the major part is under reconstruction. Don't get discouraged. A foreigner living in the city advised me that it is worth the visit despite the reconstruction. She was right. The guy selling ticket at the entrance
Remarkable medieval fortress ruins with fantastic well preserved garden. There are so many hidden corners to explore by watching the storks on top of the trees, towers and walls.

We walked from our riad in the medina to the Chellah. It was an easy enough walk, and we got to see some of Rabat on our way. We really enjoyed visiting the ruins, which were well preserved. It's a peaceful spot, with a good amount to see.
Wandering around Chellah in this beautiful and generally very quiet part of Rabat, was a special experience.

Visited this place on my recent trip to Rabat. Spend an hour or so such a serene and quiet place. Better to visit in the afternoon. Good view of the rabat city from this place.
This beautiful garden and archialogical site is the perfect place to spend a few hours wandering around.

Ancient Roman ruins within a stone's throw of downtown old Rabat. Within its walls, lie a garden and multiple ruins, many of which are in quite good repair and definitely worth seeing. Also interesting to watch are the storks which abound on the walls and towers! Great for

The capital city of Rabat is beautiful, clean and elegant. Stopping by the Chellah is one of the many scenic spots to visit.

This is a truly lovely place. We visited in August 2019. You can go around on your own or you can get a guide inside who will take you around. Best to decide on the price of the guide beforehand. Best time to visit is early morning.

If you are interested in archeology (and even if you aren't) this is the top attraction in Rabat. The site may be second to Volubilis and may not compare to sites in Turkey, but it is not to be missed. Terrific historical significance!

It is a must when visiting Rabat. Chellah is well structured, with good information boards around the place. Roman ruines are well preserved and the stork nests are an attraction. Bring your telephoto lens!

This is what you want to see that is in your thoughts as to what is Morocco. Imagine how it was hundreds of years ago. Lots of pictures opportunities. A must to visit.
A great place to walk in the steps of history interactions with real ancient items and structures that were in classical style
Originally a place for retired Roman soldiers this is an interesting site with great gardens. Stork nests are interesting. Don't need too much time here
Our tour group stopped here and we walked the grounds. Lots of stork nests. Ruins were interesting. Nice gardens and shady areas to rest in. Bathrooms were good.

A Roman city wrapped inside a moorish fortified city - if you are a history buff there is nothing better. There is an option to take a guided tour and some locals that offer; I would not bother and go exploring and climb the ruins. Not to be missed
As we were on a coach tour we didn't have as long as we would have liked to explore but what we did see was very interesting.
A nice stroll through ruins, lovely gardens and wildlife. Many cats, and Storks nesting in towers. The story of the ladies swimming is interesting ......you’ll have to go to find out.
I had though the Kasba was amazing but this place is truly the best place to visit in Rabat. You can’t miss it while you’re in town
Romans in Marocco, apparently they were all over the place. Nice site to visit. one hour seems to be enough. Htere are also some old islamic ruins
Untoughted archaeology site with amazing view of the city. Not very crowded with tours, so it's more enjoyable.
Ideal place for lovers of ruins and antiquity where you can walk and meditate in peace. I would come back very often in the future because I could not visit all the sites.
Interesting site but not anything spectacular. Small area of Roman ruins and Muslim ruins. Warning many steps and a significant hill to climb up to exit the ruins.

Go early so that it is not too hot! I was very impressed to see this! The main tower where the storks were perched was how I was able to guide myself thru this maze of history. It is a lot of walking and a lot of history. From what used to be a small pool to kids class room

Chella is an interesting prospect when in town. Sitting on the outer edge about 20 minutes walk from the main station will bring you to this attraction. It really is worth the effort and will reward those that pay the 70 MAD entry. Chella is a walled Roman town with an old
impressive ancient settlement and Roman ruins. Our guide Aziz gave a very interesting background of the site, made the visit so much more interesting. Also get to observe a lot of storks in the area
We really enjoyed the laid back experiences in Rabat compared to other spots in Morocco. Food here was very good.
We had a guide and he was able to fill us in on the history that was not written on the nearby places. There is an entrance fee but we enjoyed seeing the ruins from the Romans and Carthage’s past.

While traveling in Rabat, we stopped and visited the necropolis at Chellah. It was very interesting to visit these ruins. The entrance / exit gate to this facility was very impressive. We enjoyed seeing the ruins of the mosque and visualized how beautiful it must have been in
This destination is far from the medina (although walkable) but worth the detour. Picture mossy Roman ruins, Muslim antiquities, lush garden paths and a large colony of storks!
Loved it, as it shows the past of rabat and also a great place to visit while you are in rabat. Great tea also
Great as part of a walking tour with historic ruins from the 15th century as well as ruins from an ancient Roman city.

Our first look at ancient necropolis, and our guide, who was very knowledgable shared many facts and stories with us that made it very interesting. I would suggest here, you try to visit with a professional guide who can explain the whole story so you can appreciate everything
Nice place, interesting to see all the ruins and read the explanations. Only 70 dirham for entrance!

Apart from the obvious ruins and the great care taken not to improve, the grounds and gardens are stunning, worth going just see them. Very chilled atmosphere came out very relaxed.

This was fascinating. the roman ruins are all over Europe but to see ruins here was unexpected. The Phoenicians founded and later Muslims conquered, but still the blending of the buildings on the site made it fascinating. Plus you have eels in the pool and storks in nests all
The Chellah is a must see with some wonderful Roman ruins and plenty of great places to take photos and it's free

The Chellah is a necropolis and Roman city with surrounding gardens and an old mosque. Near the mosque, there is also a pool where childless women feed eggs to eels in the hope of conceiving. This place is one to read about before you go or watch You Tube videos. I have seen
Nice walk and easy to get around that around. As tourists, there're also many other spots near-by. Not bad to have a look, while don't expect a lot inside.
The place is great. You can feel the power of the past. Don't go if you don't have water or food with you. There is nothing there. P.S. Don't go on foot!!!

This is on the outskirts of the city walls and is very relaxing to walk around. It’s 70 d to get in and they take euro. The ruins are at the bottom of the hill but it’s an easy walk. I found the big colony of stalks interesting.

This historic place was with ZERO restoration. They could have made it much better with spending some money on restoration of this famous historic site
This is a real must see when visiting Rabat. Especially the medersa and all the storks at their nests are very impressive.
Good to visit but not great interesting and easy to visit and part of old part of city and important

This place is vast and storks are everywhere to see. Loved it! The place (during our visit) was not crowded and we were able to easily explore the ruins. Highly recommended. Especially because of the storks.
Very interesting historical site with so many storks and cats among old Roman ruins. You can view everything within 2 hours.

Beautiful place to walk around, take in the scenery, learn about the history. Can easily do on your own.

Roman ruins on the site of an early Phoenician settlement with a later mosque and mausoleum. Very interesting and well tended. 70 MAD pp in cash entry fee, but worth it. Close to the palace - allow 45 minutes and be prepared for a steep walk to return.
The highlight of my trip to Rabat. 70 dirhams for non-Moroccans to visit. Lots of storks around the grounds are very vocal!
Well worth a visit. There is an entrance fee of €7 but worth a visit. Very well preserved. Chella dates back to 1286 and absolutely incredible

Enter the walls to view acres of ancient ruins, many of which still outline the crumbling buildings. Each high position seems to hold a stork nest, adding life and interest to the scene. Some challenges for those with mobility issues, but worth the effort, even if you can't tour

Not too far from the city. Mildly interesting. Under renovation. Do not spend too much time here if you intend covering Volubilis later.

Sadly I did not have much time to explore the Chellah site which comprises the substantial remaining walls and gardens. What I did see was fascinating as were the storks and their nests.

Absolutely amazing. The Roman ruins were impressive. We were there in the winter when the storks were nesting on the tops of the ruins. The cats who lived there also were cute. I would highly recommend visiting here.

Should mainly go visit for the outside walls, which are glooming red at sunset. There is a colony of stalks in and out of the compound which is pretty awesome. The ruins are ok, but wouldn’t recommend them in particular.
10 minuits in the Taxi from the centre this Roman Site is worth a visit it's situated Just outside the Town centre brings you into another World It must be seen !
For lovers of gardens and ruins, legends and cats,it's a promenade you can't miss if you visit Rabat
A walled citadel containing Phoenician,Roman,Berber and Arab ruins.A ruined Merinid mosque is especially beautiful.The storks now have it all to themselves!!!
Among the ruins were beautiful gardens and a pool with an eel. Women bring eggs hoping for fertility. There are lots of cats making the area peaceful.

We went to Chellah with our guide Youssef who once again was excellent. We strolled through the Roman ruins, enjoyed the serenity of the gardens and watched the storks nests. We went there early (before 10:00 am) and were able to soak in peacefully the beauty of the place and

We went in our second day in Rabat because after Mausoleum, Medina amd the becah...it's the next "must see" in the city. Honestly for the prices of the city the entrance it's a bit expensive to be Morroco, normal for Europe but not here. Was 7€ that in Spain it's normal but here

We really enjoyed exploring these ruins. Of course we visited here the day before we had the wonderful experience of visiting Volubilis so it was a lovely introduction. It was fun to have such incredible access to just roam where you choose and climb among all of the ruins.
The Roman ruins are remarkable and prepare you for a trip to Volubilis. We were fascinated by the storks that also lived there.

Even if a bit outside the city center (not that remote though) it is extremly secure both inside and outside. It is one of the major spots to visit in Rabat if you are on a cultural trip (roman and islamic archeology) Prices of entry are cheap, they offer discounts too, warm
Here you get to see the ruins of a Roman city that was located at this site.There are also ruins from Sultan Aba Said and storks build their large nests on the grounds.
lovely gardens w many plants, trees, flowers be prepared for humidity, as you walk through you come upon the necropolis [ancient ruins] startling-shouldn't be missed
Good for an hour or two walk around the ruins. Descriptions only in Arabic or French, 70MAD to get in now for foreigners.
If you’re interested in the historical significance of the Moroccan country, you cannot miss this location. It’s worth the long walk down loose steps to see the ruins.

Drove to Citadel of Chellah Gardens. Cost us 70 MAD to get in, free for Moroccan citizens. Noted for 100’s of flowers in bloom in the spring. This time of year there were many fruit trees and a few flowering bushes in bloom. Many storks have huge nests throughout the property.

Really beautiful gardens, my 9 yr old was captivated by the plants and tress. Views, ruins pretty amazing too. The storks are great to watch as are the eels. We spent much longer there that we thought we would. Def a highlight of Rabat, and a place I'd never heard of until I

This archaeological gem is obligatory in Rabat. It is well preserved, and there are good views of the sister city across the river.
great way to spend an hour or so wandering round the ruins such history and so well maintained amazing

A very interesting place. An old muslim area, an old Roman area and a very nice garden combin together with great amounts of Storks (and a lot of cats happy to be cuddled) make for a nice centuries spanning experience. getting a guide is highly recommended. As the Roman ruins

Expensive entry fee. Guide pushy. All signs in French only. Despite all this the ruins are very interesting and make for good photo opportunities. The high outer wall belies the treasures within. One can walk over some of the ruins - which is not ideal to their preservation.

Mostly ruins and trees. Also we saw LOTS of storks - and cats. Nothing that really has to be seen but nice to spend an hour or two.
Enter another world as you explore these ruins from the days of Roman occupation. The ruins have been stabilised and the gardens maintained to make the area attractive and interesting to vidit
First settled this place Fenician people, after 40 AD Sala Colonia start development of town. Nice walking through gardens and ruins.

Chellah is a good place to spend an hour or two. The ruins are interesting, and the whole place is quite pretty. Well worth a visit.

Definitely a must-see in Rabat. The entrance fee is 10 Dirhams, which is reasonable for this attraction. At the entrance, you are greeted by a colossal ancient door. Inside, there are splendid gardens and ruins from the Romans, as well as ruins of an ancient mosque. There are

For someone who is fond of Roman ruins, this was an unexpected treat. In addition the gardens were a delight. Look out for the storks who are now the residents of the former necropolis, like sentinels guarding the lost souls.

It was a good visit, though I wish I read either Arabic or French to be able to understand the signage of the place. Beautiful garden and outlook views! I am a bit thrilled to see the historical ruins and the birds gliding over them.

I've been here twice and I loved the experience. Knowing all the civilizations that have chosen this fort and walking down its historical ramparts make you travel back in time hundreds of years ago... Even if not completly restored, the fort still has proofs of roman presence,
Well preserved, nice garden, good for photos. I would have benifited from a guided tour. Walked here in under an hour from Rabat Station.
An interesting archaeological site and gardens to wander about for an hour or two. The minaret which has been taken over by storks is perhaps the central attraction
Very nice monument with exotic garden and remarkable landscape. Some local people offer you to guide inside the site.
We enjoyed walking around the ruins but weren’t blown away. I’d recommend it if in the area. We spent about 40 mins looking around before moving on. The entrance fee was fair.

Chellah is tge walled fort built by the Roman in a dramatic position looking down on the river. its ruins are just a short walk from the medina of Rabat. It is one of the most visited tourist attraction as it has both roman and muslim influence. Storks nets csn be seen on the

These ruins were definitely worth viewing, especially if you read about it before you see it. (That is assuming you know nothing about the history of Morocco). Viewing allows one to realize how very old this area is and how the Arabs adapted the site for their own use.

There are so many things to see here, ruins of mosque, a garden, lots of storks nests and the chance to see these fabulous birds quite close up, Roman remains and great views over the neighboring landscape. This is a place to linger, I never had time to visit it all.

The Chellah Necropolis is well worth a visit. It is on the edge of the main part of Rabat, easy to access. It is essentially ruins, some in better repair than others. The storks have taken over which adds to the photogenic quality of the site. It is a bit of walk downhill to
I think Chellah is the best historical landmark of Rabat. You can find the remnants of Merinides, Roman and Phoeinikan trade colonies. Also there is an necropolis area established by Merinides.

As I have mentioned in other reviews, I thought that Rabat was nice without being particularly notable. The highlight of our visit was Chellah, which is a great place to wander round, with Roman ruins and nice gardens. I agree with others that the Storks stole the show. We

Inside an ancient Moroccan wall, descend hill down well maintained stone steps. Shady and beautiful plantings. At end of garden a huge viewing platform to the Roman ruins below and across the valley and the storks nesting everywhere. I wasn't as wild about the eel pond, but
Chellah has a nice mix of exotic plants and old ruins. With nice weathe chellah is a peaceful place to spend an hour or so walking at a leisurely pace.

Easy to spend an hour or two wondering around the ancient ruins, feeding the hoard of cats, strolling through the gardens or watching the storks who nest on numerous ruin tops and old mosques. Intriguing place full of hundreds of years of history.
