We taxied out and walked back in to town. Arrived about 10.30a.m. so it was quiet but filling up as we left. We loved the site. Of course the storks added to the visit with their mating clacking ritual.

The Chella is spectacular with beautiful gardens ( filled with clacking storks nesting everywhere) and roman ruins and fortifications from various periods of Moroccan dynasties - Rabat is the modern capital but was edge of Roman Mauretania. It is very peaceful and not touristy.
The first time we visited Rabat, we did not have time to go to Chellah. This time we did and we can recommend it. Really very interesting.

Beautiful spot with ancient history and archeology, very quiet. An ancient Roman ville and an ancient moske and ancient graves in a castle with a big and calm garden. You will see many cats and even more storks.
The gardens are beautiful. It is amazing to see history being covered over several centuries. The stork nests through out the site add a unique element to your visit.
One of the few places where you can explore Roman ruins completely unfettered. No ropes, no guards, no fuss at all. Go where you like and see everything up close. Really amazing place.

Fully agree with several reviewers, a visit to Chellah is a worthwhile part of Rabat tour. This is a place filled with history of several eras. It is good to have guide to get the most out of your visit. Storks are everywhere in these ruins -- providing good photo opportunities.
Loved it here. So beautiful and peaceful and filled with history of many eras. The storks everywhere building nests were amazing. Don't miss this and give it some time. A little piece of paradise.

At the Chellah you will find history / architecture from the Phoenicians, Romans, and Medieval Muslims. To cap it all, there are wuite a few storks who have made their nests on the site of the abandoned mosque, so a great place for birdwatching too. A must see location in Rabat

I can’t get over how many different plants are here from what I consider different eco systems. Tropical and succulents and stuff I’ve never seen like the plant border that looked like it had bugs but it was the flower in the middle of the leaf! Lots of stork nests easy to

We walked here from town and there’s a busy road to get over but once you do, it’s outside the city and a really interesting spot where you can see the estuary and what I think is a salt marsh. The site is really calm and pleasant with very little hassle. Take your time to

A beautiful place to visite. There are both excavations here of an old roman city, and a newer ruin of a mausoleum and a mosque. The vegetation is lushious with orange trees, bamboo and large trees. And then there’s the storks. There are so many of them. They nest on the top of

Chellah looks impressive - a real Moorish fort in the heart of Rabat - however this is only the tip of the impressive history that the high walls hide. Inside Chellah is a beautiful garden where exotic birds. There to behold was a bath house, governance chamber and other

We visited in the morning and the light was beautiful. The outside is fully restored so pretty upon approach and a nice garden. Inside the old roman ruins and roman road are compelling, and the 13-14th Century tombs and ruins with some mosaics (and more than 100 storks) are

A city that traces its origins to the Carthaginian and Phoenicians. You can walk around the ruins and imagine what it was like. They have beautiful trees and vegetation’s throughout. A wonderful place to take a lot of pictures. Interestedly enough, there are over 70 stork nests
Ancient fortress provides up close views of storks as well as interesting historical information. Took lots of pictures.
We visited here on our first full day in Morocco. It was delightful. Very scenic and offers the chance for many excellent photo opps. I'd love to return.

We arrived at Chellah in the afternoon when the golden sunlight danced on the Roman ruins. Our guide met us inside the ancient walled citadel and gave an interesting commentary as we passed by remains of a holy necropolis and complex including mosque, minaret, and royal tombs.
A very good stay in this Chellah. All kind of plants are growing inside. Very nice view of the Roman and Arabic “houses”. A lot of birds.

We arrived at this place to see the French dugout for Roman treasure but place is the burial ground. There is a little water pool believed to be the wishing Well. Plantation around the place was being well maintained.

A nice place to visit in the afternoon - sunset or morning. Amazing for photos and opportunity to see storks in the upper parts of the walls of the ruins. Beautiful site, and one of the must see places in Rabat.
Highly recommended collection of Roman ruins, enhanced by numerous stork nests and a lot of cats. Well worth visiting.

Small site with Roman and Berber remains in a walled enclosure. Worth a visit for the sense of layered history but not overly well maintained and the remains are of limited visual interest. Focus tends to be on the many storks that nest in the ruins.
We were here at the end of the day, wich meant that we had the beautiful sunset to glow up the whole place. We did find it hard to imagine everything so a guide could me recommended.
This park with ancient ruins, just outside the Rabat city walls, houses many storks and cats. A beautiful and quiet place, for a little exploring and relaxing.

The Chellah, is a medieval fortified Muslim necropolis located in the metro area of Rabat, Morocco, on the south side of the Bou Regreg estuary. The Phoenicians established a trading emporium at the site and called it "Sala".

A marvelous expanse of Phoenician, Roman and Muslim ruins. I love this kind of place, it was not crowded the day I was there, and that allowed for quiet exploration of the various ruins, as well as observing the many storks perched in trees and the tops of ancient walls. One
This was the last stop of my trip to Morroco and whar a wonderful place. Just what I needed to reflect facing the ocean.

We really enjoyed this place because of the history that played out in this space over the centuries. There are wonderful Roman and Moorish ruins to explore and it's helpful to have a guide. It was fun seeing the roosting cranes, as well.
nothing extraordinary but pleasant quiet and lovely nature around. Ticket very cheap. Do not use the guide, it is a waste of money

It was quite a trek to walk from near the Cathedral but we made it! Full of school children when we visited so sadly were not able to enjoy the site as much. There are Roman ruins which didn't really interest us as we have seen more impressive ones elsewhere. The highlight was

You get gardens, you get Islamic ruins, you get Roman ruins, you get the gate, you get the walls, you get a pond with heels that hide in holes and come out when fed, you get hundreds of cats, you get dozens of storks... there is simply so much to see and a ton of photo

This interesting historic site is a bit outside of Rabat’s centre, but worth the walk or taxi ride. First, one walks through a nice garden down to the Roman ruins. There is also the ruins of a mosque. There are at least a dozen of storks nesting. Highly recommended! The downside
This archaeological site you must visit.The Roman Ruins are still here.Take a good guide to elaborate. Worth the visit.

beautiful place to take a stroll thru the wonderful gardens and ruins. In antique times it was a major producer of guaram fish sauce. salt was worth it's weight in gold. delightful to see all the storks nesting for the winter!

Stopped here as part of a Rabat tour. The walls and building were beautiful. All well maintained and the people inside very very nice. Could have spent more time here exploring the many alleyways. Would love to come back

This historic location was worth visiting. We spent about an hour here and could have spent another hour walking the grounds. There are ruins from the time of the Roman occupation that you can walk through and several stork nests at the tops of the buildings. From here you can

We visited this spot for an hour during our drive through Morocco. It is lovely- the area is well taken care of and you can walk around all the ruins. There is quite a mix of religious influences. Guided tours are available (all the signs are in Arabic or French so you may want
very well maintained and clean, A pity no explanations in English - only french and Arabic. Without a guide you require a good guidebook.

Chellah is a fascinating place where Phoenicians, Romans, Muslins, and Marinids used the site over centuries. You start at the top and progress down wide steps to the garden that is at the bottom. Storks nest is the minaret of remains of the Mosque. Friendly cats roam the

This is a pleasant place to walk and relax away from the hustle of the city. The paths are not all accessible for wheelchair users or those with limited mobility. When I visited there were lots of cranes nesting, they are beautiful birds! Worth it to see them in flight. There

The Chellah has a mysterious quality to it that has not been lost to the modernization around it. You can sense the antiquity of the place, even before you see the Roman ruins at the bottom of path. How many peoples have lived and died on that hill side? Then when you add to it

Peaceful walk amongst the Roman and moroccons ruins and necropolis...the information is all in Arabic or French...no English so if you don't have a guide you are kind of clueless... nevertheless I enjoyed walking amongst the ruins...

The ancient ruins of a Roman city are enjoyable to walk through. We visited on a hot day and it was lovely to stroll through the gardens and ruins. We were fortunate to see the stork nests on the ruins. Although we had a guide it is worthwhile reading up on the area before you

The Kasbah Chellah includes Roman ruins c200 BC - 300 AD, as well as early Moroccan, Islamic buildings representing living space, school, and mosque. Story nests high up on many protrusions from this historic site. Our group ended up taking as many pics of storks as they did
This necropolis has a nice garden. There are many storks and ibis. The excavations are excellent. The explanations are in French.
Roman and islamic ruines, beautiful garden, a sanctuary of cats and storks. Must see. Symbolic fee, equivalent to 1 eur.
This was a really interesting place to visit, with so much history. I loved the mosaics on the mosque and the baths. Well worth seeing thus Roman site.
It was hot but the views were so beautiful. The ruins were beautiful. I felt taken back in time. This is a must see. It was only 10 dirhams to enter.
Historical place of the Merinidian time with bathhouse, garden and necropolis; Roman houses and graves

We wandered around Chellah for a few hours. There were some great photo opportunities and lovely views across the bay. It's worthwhile if you have a morning or afternoon to spare and unlike much of morocc, there is very little hassle to buy or indulge, from locals.

Because this is such an important historical attraction, reading about its background would make the visit more interesting and more worth it. Several civilizations have governed the country and each one has added to the importance of this city. This place is a feasible walk

We had a lovely morning walk of this stunning backdrop. Here we saw what used to be great elegance and still is. The lands and gardens are consistently tended to and even the schools brought visiting children to the monument during our stay. It's worth a visit.

It was an excellent evening as part of the Jazz festival at Chellah. The evening was nice and the day we visited all the roman ruins etc. I highly recomend a tour guide for this one. The cost is minimal and the story is interesting and you need to hear it.
Impressive ruins and nice garden. It's definitely a "must-see" in Rabat. You can make wonderful photos there.
What a lovely place to spend on a hot day with the shade of the gardens, a pleasant walk and the offer of Roman and Muslim ruins. Very good
This is an old Roman ruin with a beautiful garden. You should wear sunscreen since there is a wide and big area under a really hot sun...
Excellent site containg Roman ruins and subsequent Muslim ruins. Entrance fee 10 dirhams. Not being in a tour group allows time to wander at will among the ruins and bsorb the feel of the place.

This is a cool pleasant garden with walking tracks through avenues of green. There is also a Roman ruin here, partly excavated, partly original and partly (minimally) restored. A pleasant diversion for us on a warm day.
The ruins were fascinating. It was amazing to walk amongst such antiquity. The garden is beautiful too.

Was suggested we had a look, wandered there from the medina, not a bad walk if you can handle the heat. Anyway, got there and hardly any tourist. The place is being rescued so the walls are rebuilt. Inside you can see many centuries of occupation in the ruins. Worth a look, but

If you are in Rabat and have any free time, you must visit Chellah. The tour book made this site seem like it was in an utter state of disrepair, but I was impressed all around. Many staff were tending to the flowers and all the giant storks and expansive nests were a special

Chellah was amazing to see. Its like revisiting an old palace / fort . It was amazing to see all the ruins and landscape with a lot of historical history. Tour guides available upon entrance to further give background history of this attraction. Definitely recommended.

As we stayed downtown close to the Rabat Ville train station, we decided we could walk to Chellah. It is about a 20 minute walk. The place has an enjoyable garden, Roman ruins, and Islamic monuments as well. We really liked the place. It would have been great if it has a cafe

A great change of a tourist attraction, from the usual medina and kasbahs of Rabat. Come here to see Roman and Moroccan Muslim ruins in a small space. It's easy to walk around and complete your exploration of the venue within an hour. It's not far from the centre of Rabat,

My family and I visited the Chellah as part of a Casablanca - Rabat day tour. After a short walk into a pleasant garden, you can see the Roman ruins and the storks nesting on top. We appreciated the history of the ruins and Islamic culture so much more because of our guide. We

The fortress of Chellah is a nice tourist spot. There is an entrance fee of 10 Moroccan dirhams. The people are welcoming and friendly. No need for a tour guide because the whole place is quite manageable to roam around. Nothing much to see and you can finish the whole place in

I did not expect to find so many well preserved structures at the Chellah. The ruins are spread out over a large area, with lots of nooks and corners with surprises. Quite manageable although there are some steps and elevated areas, but a good view of both the Roman remains and

The Chellah is a short cab ride outside the downtown of Rabat. Entry is inexpensive and the walk down through the gardens to the ruins takes you back twenty centuries to roman times. Many of the ruins are guarded by storks under whose gaze you constantly walk. The site contains

Wow!!! Surreal and breathtaking! The architecture is stunning! The history fascinating. Not worth hiring a guide. Strolling through the ruins at your own leisurely pace is more rewarding and pleasurable.

Visit Chellah near the Royal Palace and discover one of the rarest Roman ruins in Rabat. The outside walls of Chellah were recently renovated/ repairs to give it even a better look at night. We recommend including it in all tours of Rabat

The Chellah is great for spending an hour, learning about the original trade settlement of the Phoenicians and Romans, and it's later use by Muslim rulers. The ruins are quite well exhibited and accessible, but the storks who nest in droves really steal the show. Very worthwhile

The Roman ruins and the gardens are very nice but we absolutely loved how close we could get to many stork nests and their chicks , they were all over the top of the Roman ruins and a clicking sounds they made were very interesting.

Nature and archeology in the midst of the city - an impressive combination. The chellah is a spiritual oasis and well worth the visit. After entering, follow the main path all the way down the hill. Wander throughout the mosque until you find the abandoned pools and wonderful

Situated just outside the city walls of Rabat, Chella is a beautifully landscaped site with Roman and Moroccan remains. The Roman remains are are mostly at foundation level, Moroccan remains are a couple of stories high - and impressive. Overall, the stars of this site are the

I liked this place more than the old town. It's very quiet, which adds to the Charme. I was practically on my own. The ruins are beautiful and the dozens of storks and stork nests add to the atmosphere. Feels almost a little enchanted. Definitely worth the hike out of the city

We were fortunate to have a very knowledgable guide to take us through the Chellah. He explained to us the time line and wove interesting facts together. We thank Aziz for making our visit so informative and interesting. The comment he made about the layout of the gardens -

We visited the Chellah ruins as part of our tour. While the ruins were quite interesting, most stunning were all the storks and their associated nests. About halfway through I switched out my regular camera lens for my long zoom telephoto lens for birds. I recommend the visit

This Historic ruin is undergoing a major restoration and landscape enhancement making it one of the best attractions in town. It is also a nice peaceful getaway as well. If you are fortunate to visit April/May you will encounter more storks than you ever dreamed of nesting here

As compared to the Mohammed V Square, this is a quiet, green space. Its fun to view the storks nesting on top of walls, columns, wherever. clack clack. the gardens at the back are pretty and the water running through "cools you" visually. the ruins are interesting to walk

A visit to Chellah will allow you to see interesting ruins and gardens. Our visit in May allowed us the unique opportunity to see huge stork nests with the nesting storks. Amazing! Our guide was informative about the site and the storks as well. They return to the site every

Not far from Fez lies the ruins of Chellah, dating to 1339 and built by Abou Yacoub Youssef as the site for a mosque and burial place for his wife. The outer wall was built sometime before 1351 by Sultan Abou Yacoub, possibly as a reconstruction of the original Roman walls.

Chellah is one of my favourite places, maybe ever. It has an amazing history, stretching from Phonecian and Roman inhabitors, through Amazigh (Berber) and Arab dynasties. There are Roman ruins, the stunning ruins of a mosque, with ancient, beautiful tiles, and a lovely garden.
This was a great stop. The ruins were very interesting, and the storks and their huge nests were vertical entertaining

Entry was 10 MAD per person (less than £1 pp). They are currently doing a lot of restoration work so there was a fair bit of scaffolding around. A kind tour guide explained the map to us and offered his services to which we declined but he seemed very knowledgeable so if that's

The Kasbah Chellah was a very fascinating experience. We were greeted at the entrance by two colourfully clad men dancing to some traditional Moroccan / African (?) music. The site is historic for two reasons, there are Roman ruins dating back to 3-4th Century AD and the
very nice place near the central of Rabat the exhibition was very nice we were in April and we saw the storks so nice on the tob of the ruins

I felt very spoilt to not only visit historical roman ruins but to also be amongst , ruins, gardens and storks. My first encounter since visiting Morooco. It was wet unfortunately, but it did NOT detract from such a beautiful historic location in Rabat. The Chellah ruins I
We loved Chellah! Nice gardens, fabulous Roman ruins with good explanations, although English descriptions would have been good. Great storks & it's good to see restoration & preservation happening.
i love gardens, n its good to feel that you sit in the garden of a Kindom frm Century ambience that suit to fell how life to be appreciated due the the sunrays that shinning frm a tree top.
So much to see in such a small area. Ruins, gardens and storks...oh my! Nice break from the heat along the shaded paths.

I really like ruins and this one didn't disappoint. Plenty of beautiful arched stoneways to see and history to visit. There were also a tons of storks there with big huge nests. I had never seen storks in real live person before and didn't realize they were so big. But back
Excellent place to visit - although quite a walk out of Rabat. Interesting islamic ruins and also an archaeological site from Roman times. Gardens quiet and restful. Never seen so many storks!

This is a 14th century Merinid necropolis. It's too bad portions haven't been better preserved, but you can still get a sense for how the place once was. As is typical for this time of year in Morocco, storks were nested everywhere.

This mosque is in garden area but ancient Phoenicians set the tone. The old Sultan's burial place is here. The river passing through separates the city of Rabat to that of Sala. Cranes are present and their best were very visible. An ancient and medieval history that is

Entrance fee at 1 euro approx and you spend some quality time to a monument highly linked the moroccan history. Good shades throughout the paths and 45 minutes guided tours also available on the spot.
Recommend this to all visitors to Rabat. Interesting to see and a different insight into Morocco. Takes about an hour.

Waw! a wonderful impact, the walls of an old Roman citadel which later became a Koranic school where the two cultures blend using the tanks of the Roman baths as eto tanks ablutions before Muslim prayers or where to swim the sacred eels. A botanical garden of great value that

Definitely worth the visit, very cheap (10 MAD), I got there really early at around 8:30, and for a full hour, I had the full site for myself! I enjoyed the nature and the history, signs are only in Arabic and French, so if you don't speak any, do your reading in advance. Even

We loved our visit here. You can pay a guide 100 dh and he will tell you the history of the place. The gardens with jasmine and mimosa flowers are so sweet smelling. The architecture of the fort and Roman ruins are all part of the charm. My favorite part was the storks nest on

I might have benefitted more from hiring a guide, so I could have learnt more about the history of the place. There are explanatory signs, but they are in French and Arabic. Nevertheless, its a beautiful, tranquil, green space that is wonderful for wandering. I loved the stork

Worth the stop! Quite a bit of walking and steps so take your time and bring some water. It's beautiful and a great part of Rabat's history. They are currently doing some restoration, but it's still open.
Chellah is a Quiet and Peaceful Historical place, don't miss an Interesting Tree Shaped Like a Dragon

This is an impressive site - with some interesting Roman and Islamic remains. There are some useful signs (in French and Arabic). It has an interesting history and is a site with significant history. The gardens are very well presented. Work is in progress on restoration.

This is, so far, one of my favorite places in Morocco. Started off with an easy 20 dirham taxi ride from Agdal to get here and then was pleasantly surprised by the lack of big bus loads of tourist groups. Only 10 dirham to enter. This place was quiet and calm with some beautiful

The experienced traveler is always seeking places where s/he can have at the same time a real discovery and peace.... Crowded places, full of selfy-tourist are the enemies of the expert and constant traveler..... Chellah is one of these few places where you can discover and rest
Amazing! Chellah is a must see in Rabat. I felt out of this world when i visited it and couldn't stop taking pictures!

Chellah is a typical Roman ruin- similar to those you find throughout Italy and in Rome especially. In that regard, it's nothing special, except for the additional ruins dating back to the 1400's that were built side by side with the ruins. There's hundreds of storks nesting in
In a lush and beautiful setting. 10 Dh entrance fee. Under renovation. You must See the Islamic complex, which houses a Big group of storks.

Chellah is a beautiful ruin, and what's so special about it is the freedom you have as a visitor to explore it! Surrounded by a wall, Chellah allows you a moment of peace from the bustling city. I can't remember - it's either free or very cheap to enter. And gorgeous!!
My favorite tourist attraction in Rabat! This place is amazing, so many photo opportunities and such a cultural experience. Also there are storks and their nests about the ruins! A must see.

Chellah is fairly close to the heart of Rabat so it's worth a quick visit. In addition to the ruins, there's a spring-fed creek and a mini-oasis on the grounds. And, depending when you visit, you'll see countless storks flying about while building nests.
Interesting archeological site containing a variety of levels of ancient civilisations. A bit haphazard,no facilities other than toilets.

This is in the outskirts of Rabat, and consists of both Roman and 14th century Merenid ruins. When one enters, the Roman ruins are on the left and the Merenid on the right. The Arabic ruins are better preserved, and you can walk through a multitude of different rooms, as well as
This restaurant is good for date nights or grown up dinner, not for kids. The food is good, atmosphere is very cozy. Good service. There is a band and nice music. They serve alcohol as well.
Amazing and interesting historical place, I consider it as a must-see spot once you're in Rabat city.

There are ancient Roman ruins combined with an ancient Mausoleum. Today, there are some jazz events organized out here, or you can come and walk around the grounds for 10dh. There may be a few men near the entrance tempting to guide you around, but I find it's more peaceful to

Walking this archeological site in progress is an experience not to miss. The storks best everywhere and are active and entertaining. The sense of place in the recovered baths and living areas is a great experience for all ages.
We took a taxi to this site and were most impressed. The ruins are interesting and there were many vestiges of the roman town. Worth a visit.
I enjoy the gardens, the cats everywhere, and the ruins ! A place to go when wanting to enjoy a book, or just looking for a peaceful balade :)
This venue has something for everyone - Roman ruins, lovely gardens, interesting architecture and remains of a mosque. Plenty of cats and birds for the animal lover too!

This archaeological Roman and Islamic site, is quiet unique for it shows that both cultures lived respectfully next to each other around the year 750 AD. That's why most of the site was still found intact. The site is in the winter occupied with many, many Storks, nesting on all

Once the site of a Roman trading & shipping center, you still see the shop cells. Very well maintained & very tranquil.. except when the storks start acting up, it's quite a chatter, & there are many storks.if you're having fertility issues, don't forget to bring your boiled

This is our second visit of Rabat. The first was very short and we only saw Oudayas. This time, we spent a bit more time looking around and went to Chellah, which is an old fortified castle that includes roman ruins. We first wandered around and really liked the atmosphere of
Beautiful and interesting garden + ruins, easily accessible. Very old and full of history, surrounded by a beautiful nature.

I strongly suggest to visit the ancient Chellah of Rabat; it is a magic place in which you can stay surrounded by nature and ancient ruins. You can also see many many storks and their nests. Spend one hour at the Chellah, it's worth!

Really enjoyed the visit.Wandering around the ruins.Admiring the plants.Looking at the stocks and their nests and listening to the sound they made .Peaceful and relaxing.Not many people and no traffic noise.

We visited this site on a saturday morning. Repairs/renovations to the outer walls were in progress. The gardens are lovely and have a wide range of plants. The ruins evoked, for me, images of the bygone peoples occupying the site. We accepted the offer of an unofficial guide.

Historically, the Roman and the Phoenicians used this area geographically as a trading route. Chellah a.k.a. Sala Colonia was once a Roman town that bustled with activity. Muslim conquerors named the area Sala and the name remains. Romans were here first, then the Marinids.
Chella is a beautiful and peaceful place to spend some time while in Rabat. Ruins, gardens, views of the city and cats!

This place has a special freshness about it just after the rain. The ruins are worth a visit and the old minaret is quite stunning. There are dozens of stork nests on top of the ancient ruins and friendly cats lazing around. Very peaceful.

This a particularly good spot to escape the manageable yet abundant pedestrian traffic of the old city. The park is a surprisingly quite setting with an inexpensive entrance fee of 10 MAD per adult. If cats are your thing, there are plenty of them wandering about the ruins.
This site had everything even in the rain. Herons nesting, a neat cemetery, beautiful gardens, ruins and more. Beautiful views of the city from the ruins.
The best attraction on Rabat Accessible well situated a lot of historical views and attraction to check Fun and awesome

Beware of mosquitto's and if you bring kids, keep them in eyesight. It is a nice activity for the day. It is ideal not to go when it is too hot outside, as there is not much in the way of shade cover when you are inside. You get to see some old ruins, but the nicest part is

Unfortunately the main gate is covered in scaffolding because the main gate is the interesting part. The Roman ruins are nice to wonder around. The Madras's minaret is very photogenic and the several pairs of storks make it a unique place. Ultimately, you can go wrong with a
The fact that it dates to 7th century BC and is still standing makes it worth visiting. There is a lot here to impress and it is worth the time you spend there.

Basically this is a fort with lots of ruins and gardens to explore. There are some great views and you can more or less every bit of the ruins. Admissions was only 10MAD per person and totally worth it. Be warned that there is a rather steep hill you have to go down and back up.
Great place to visit, surprisingly big and well kept. It is pleasant to walk around even on a hot day as most of it is in shade.

Did a tour of Chellah- ancient ruins that had been hidden underground. It is just amazing at the size and condition of this once city. You can walk around and see all the different areas and see some of the hand work that they did on columns and buildings. It was nice to walk

I would definitely recommend visiting the Chellah if you're in Rabat. Unlike in a lot of Europe, you can get up-close and personal with the ruins, and have access to most of the grounds. It was peaceful and breathtaking. There are many signs to educate you on what you're
Amazing place with so much mixed Arab and Roman history. Situated on higher ground overlooking the river estuary to the south of the city, quiet and peaceful. Watch out for the storks !!!
Lovely location with landscaped gardens + a few roman and other ruins and heaps of stork nests. Very scenic and photogenic....relaxing. We also enjoyed the Hassan 2 memorial and the kasbah.

This is a nice place to visit. The gardens are pretty. The old Roman ruins are a site to see. There are storks in nests all over the property. While we visited there were some young storks in the nest.

Rabat is typically not your main destination if you're going to Morocco and no doubt other cities have much more history. Nonetheless if you are in Rabat then its worthwhile to go to the Chellah, and see the remains of the Roman buildings and other architecture.

This is a must see site for anybody visiting Rabat. It has relics of Phoenician, Roman and Islamic occupation of the site. The signage is patchy, so a good guide book is a necessary companion when visiting.
Or you will be just looking at the ruins without knowing a thing about it. Everything/the info boards are in French or Arabic...

These ruins were by far my favorite over the palace and mausoleum. The gardens within are a plus (pretty and well managed) but the physical remnants of enshrined roman statues and columns that have toppled over the years was the cake!

As well as the storks chatting away in their nests on top of crumbling walls etc the Roman and onwards ruins, helped by the 1755 earthquakes that also flattened Lisbon, are reached through the impressive walls and gate and a cooling garden. Signs are in Arabic and French only.

We didn't expect too much from this visit based on our guidebook, thogh were suprised by the energy that has been put in to this place for restoration and maintenance. Furthermore it is a great mixture of buildings from Roman and Medieval/sultan times and also has a great garden

An incredibly interesting site with a lot of amazing roman ruins. A bargain as well! My advice would however be to avoid walking to the site as it is quite far from down town Rabat and you need to walk past some sensitive government buildings, with nervous military guards, to

Before we went there, I researched online for information about the opening hours, and found in several websites and blogs that it opened from 8:30a.m. to 6:30p.m.. We got there at around 5:45p.m. and it was closed. There was no information on site and they seemed to be going

Where to start...the ruins of Chellah, for me, were brilliant. Outside of the city walls, being the old city, it sits in a somewhat isolated area. The ruins are not in a great state, but they're imposing s5nd worth a visit. The gate is a great entry point.

Very evocative site with great vistas toward Sale and an opportunity to see nesting storms up close. Take a taxi (just verify price ahead) as it is quite a hike and easy to get lost despite its looking like a straight shot from the big mosque. Consider lunch and a glass of wine

Want to look at a different perspective of Morocco's history? Come to Chellah! The archeological site is really awesome and other than some rude tourists there is really everything you'd want from such a place. Guides are great and there is just so much to see! You won't regret

I visited Chellah on a Thursday afternoon. There were few other tourists there so it was quite peaceful and relaxing. These ruins cover much more area than I had anticipated so you can do quite a bit of walking to see everything. The admission price is low- only 20 dirhams.
You can runaway from noisy streets and relaxing inside beautiful gardens. Good place to visit and rest
Visit the ruins and walk around the greenery. Cheetah is relatively quiet and cool. Great place to escape the hustle of the downtown. Interesting ruins and great opportunity for photographs.

This spot is beautiful in all seasons. You can spend an hour or a few, if you are ready to just relax and entertain yourself with a book, snack or chatting. Very family friendly in terms of open space in general but some guards will whistle if kids climb on rocks or trees; often
This place is so calm and the gardens are just a place you can relax. You will also enjoy the storks flying around
Interesting way to spend a couple of hours. Signage is minimal but not really necessary if one is just enjoying the architecture. Interesting pool with huge eels. Plenty of cats as with everywhere.

Surprisingly uncrowned but fascinating glimpse into the history of the wealth of a port city. There are better preserved sites in other North African and Southern European countries but this is certainly worth a visit if you come to Rabat.

The site has a very rich heritage where it had been colonised by the Phoenicians and then later the Romans and Berbers. With the help of a guide, you understand the significance of this place and what the ruins used to be. The Moorish ramparts look absolutely stunning as the

.It is worth to visit it if you are in Rabat.do'nt doubt that the place is the most interesting places in the city.you will see elegant minaret now topped by stork's nest, Medresa,gravys and beautiful garden .with a guide you will know more about it.(we didn't have a guide).
Chellah is park, which forced me loved it. This park has ruins and that reminded me ancient Turkey or Greece. Visit it!
Interesting looking spot but it lacked information about what we were walking through. Worth a visit.

Aside from the immense history at this site, it is very beautiful and surrounded by the old medina walls. It was a pleasure to walk around the area on a Sunday afternoon. It's very relaxing and has a zen feel about it. It's also inexpensive and easily accessible.

Chellah is one of the places that get few visitors less crowd maybe because it's far from the down town,and it's one of the oldest places in Rabat "roman ruins" perfect for old culture lovers :) actually it's invaded by cats
This is of must to visit in Rabat it takes around 1 hour But if your really want to enjoy it get a tour guide to explain the sight
This is where the city started, roman ruins and first Muslim castle. Enjoy the gardens, and the view on bouregreg valley.
Touring the Roman ruins was neat, but certainly accentuated by the sound of the storks with their funny cry. Lovely little nooks in the shade that are perfect for a picnic!
Escape the hustle and bustle of the city for some peach and quiet wandering through the ruins of Chellah.

It was great to walk through the ruins and feel the sense of history throughout the grounds. A lot of interesting plants make the site beautiful. Storks are abound, nesting high in each of the towers. Very interesting experience.

This is a beautiful garden with a large variety of plants, cats, storks, and it also has the ruins. We spent a morning here and really enjoyed the sights. Bring 5dh for parking if you have car. We didn't have a guide because there weren't any who spoke English, but this was
An absolutely wonderful experience that takes you back to pre-Christian times. The stork experience (nested above) reminds one of a "Jurassic" experience.
This is a beautiful garden at first, then there are some very impressive roman ruins, and there are nests of storks everywhere. It's worth a look.

Wow what to say..... u will walk around a beautiful garden and birds. So calm and exotic we were totally in love with this garden... There are some ruins with all history explication in arab, french and english. The price is really correct.. 10 dirham for one entrance. Don't

The ruins of this ancient fortress will leave you wondering what it must have been like to live within such walls, with columns resembling something you would see in Athens mixed with tropical gardens it is a wondrous sight

Chellah is a very interesting site. Within the Islamic built walls there are Roman, Byzantine and Islamic ruins. I suggest a guide to show you around and explain the history of the site. The Roman ruins are in one central location. The best Byzantine structure is the church

Interesting and quiet place of historic value. The old Roman settlement was abandoned and Chellah basically became a ghost town. What can be seen is mostly built in the 14th century by a Merinid sultan. What struck me is that the design of the mosque built at the time has been
Chellah is quite amazing - a necropolis and ancient site housed within a very picturesque fortress. There is a small very beautiful garden there as well.

besides being a roman archeological site, a muslim necropolis, a bothanical garden...it is also a unique place for its population of storks. Amazing in their natural environment and the sound they make ...you have never heard!!!

I believe the Chellah an old crumbling palace is the most beautiful site to be visited in Rabat. It offers tranquility and beauty. Well thought out Restoration is underway. In addition the walls and the big tress are colonized by thousand of singing birds. Don't miss it.

This old Roman naval town Sala Colonia (later called Chellah) was one of the first major settlements at the banks of the Bou Regreg river. The ruins show how a Roman port grew into a medieval town until it was abandoned in the 12th century. A site to visit for history lovers.

The gardens offer a lovely stroll for those that don't mind a bit of up and down the hills. The Chellah sits majestically on the hills above the BouRegreg River, and inside its walls you can find some amazing artifacts and beautiful gardens. A wonderful place for some great

Nice ruins, gardens, clean, natural brook, many storks all around, beautiful view of city. Everything is written in Arabic and French but you can't get lost. It's really a good place to spend your time in nature and explore little details of ruins.

The Romans came, got squished by an earthquake then the Berber built a mausoleum on top. Excavation of both sites has left an interesting view of the layers of history. And the storks love the nesting sites provided by the ruins!

Quite well preserved Roman remains, guides hovering which we rebuffed. Typical of so many Roman remains although these in quite good state of repair. Stork nests dominate all the high points. They all had chicks when we were there. Cost 10R less than a pound.

It's true that one can walk around the ruins and enjoy the serenity of the gardens, but much will be missed without a tour guide to fill one in on what one is observing. The old Roman city has crumbled but there are enough remains to stimulate the imagination. The wildflowers
The ruins are all marked in arab/french so one can be quite lost without a tour guide explain what is what. Its close by to the Royal Palace, almost 15 minutes walk.

Lovely to walk around the Chellah with the highlights being the lovely ruins and the many many white stork nests on virtually every high place. They built huge nests and come back year after year (we were told) to nest and birth their young. Fascinating to watch them! The

This is a tranquil place, where you can walk among the ruins and greenery. Unfortunately very little remained of ancient town, just ruins of Triumphal arch and some columns. Nearby lies the ruined Merinid mosque, what is the reason for this ruined state is not clear, but now

Chellah is a beautiful site, preserving ancient Roman ruins in the city. The site is conveniently located, easy to get to, and well laid out. It was fascinating seeing the ruins amidst the beautiful views and rolling hills.

I took a early walk here before the hordes. They let me in without paying as they didn't have change yet. After crossing the octagonal gate, you descend a gradual path lined with beautiful trees, shrubs and plants to the ruins and structures below. It's a wonderful, tranquil
Closed to the Medina a marvelous place where to relax and enjoy the stunning colors of Morocco. Beautiful gardens and ruins. It was exciting to see all the storks nests.
The combination of ruins, garden and storks nesting made this a very interesting place to visit. Quite peaceful.

Most visitors will use a tax if not part of a coach party, though it's possible to vist here fomr the central station (15-20 minutes walk) Cost isn't usually high for such a popular attraction of the old city, in particular some remnants of how they lived Beyond the opening

Travelling through Greece, one expects to see the kind of ruins that are here in Chellah, but unlike many places in Greece, you can actually walk through the ancient ruins of Chellah and get a sense of how the various rulers organized the city. This is a 'must see' site.
nice place to visit and see the history, with very very very nice nurture views. try to go their when the weather is nice and warm.

I knew nothing about Rabat before this trip with Under Moroccan Sun tour guide, but loved the Chellah ruins. Our guide was great at sharing history (it is best to go with someone who knows the history), and I loved the nesting of the storks amidst the ruins. Such an impressive

My husband and I spent a couple of hours meandering through this ancient archaelogical site this afternoon. Well worth the time. The gardens are beautifully maintained (not a single weed in sight), lush and intensely fragrant. A delight to your senses. Surprised we could wander
Beautifully maintained gardens and ruins with dozens of storks perched on their nests. An amazing place to visit. Don't miss it.

Rabat does not have a lot of tourist attractions compared to other cities in Morocco, but if you are there for more than a day and want to go outside the Medina, then Chellah is the place to visit. It is a walled casbah, first constructed by the Romans and later witnessed an
Lovely view over the ocean and in the back allys there are nice houses, pretty in blue. But get someone to guide you around, much asier that way.

Good to see. Beautiful Roman and Arab ruins set in quaint botanical gardens. it shouldn't take more than 1 hr. There's a lot of storks who nest there and make loud clacking noises: hence the name in Arabic for a stork is: "LacLac". They have a small reservoir with eels too. But

The Chelleh's history spans time periods dating back to ancient Rome... The site includes well maintened, modern gardens and a performance spot (where concerts are held), plus fascinating old ruins from the former civilizations (towards the lower end). Be sure to stop at the
Expect a nice walk through history and hundreds of storks if you go. The place is quieter early morning before the buses arrive. Take your time and visit the whole site. I simply loved it!

This place is a must see for anyone visiting Rabat. Some of these ruins are so old and well preserved. What is surprising is how close and personal you can get to the ruins. I would love to come back here with my nice camera. There are some great photographic opportunities.
Best place in Rabat , in my opinion . Beautiful garden and landscape. Nice weather , can walk along and take a pictutes. Can see big storks everywhere ! Lovely !!

Chellah (pronounced as Shellah in Rabat) is a World Heritage Site, about 3-4 km from old city center. It comprises a well preserved fort like entrance to ruins of an ancient Roman necropolis of Sala Colonia. The kings of Muslim dynasty Almoahids later deserted this city which

I really enjoyed our visit to Chellah. We walked around the entire site and were all distracted by the colonies of nesting storks perched high above the ruins. There is history, ruins, storks and lovely views to enjoy here and it is a very peaceful place to explore. As with
Lovely mysterious place, a must see if you have an hour to spare. Especially on the busy Royal Cities tours, this is nice walk in a lush garden, with beautiful old ruins,and storks everywhere!
Chellah is definitely worth a visit. We were fascinated with this ancient site. You do have to walk down a long hill but the walkway is so well maintained and it is an enjoyable walk.

The hollow sound of clicking fills this place of ancient ruins and gardens, it is from the dozens and dozens of white storkes that nest here. Well marked, you do not really need a guide. Wonderful views
You can enjoy a nice view and learn something about history... bring some food for the stray cats ^^ they will like it And of course be careful of mosquitoes hahaha

I felt like walking the day I went to the Chellah so I walked from the Medina near the Kasbah and stuck to the main roads. Took me around 40 mins to get here nd it was truly worth it. The Chellah had a peace and tranquillity I did not expect. The entrance fee was 10dirhams.

This is a very cheap and interesting place to visit. These ruins are full of history and it is definitely worth the visit! You can also find hundreds of storks nesting all over the place.
Of all the ruins I have visited during my ten day journey in Morocco Chellah is one of my favorite because of the storks living here.
This place is really worth a visit. Great to look at the ruins, but what we really loved were the hundreds of storks nesting here

This was a very inexpensive and interesting historical site. The restoration and preservation is very well done and what I would expect at a World Heritage Site. The Chellah is a beautiful look back through the Roman period with terrific artifacts and excavations to the Berber

If you come to Rabat, you must make the time to visit this place. I stayed at the Sofitel, so walking distance (at least to me) to most of the areas with a cool history perspective.
chellah is an ancient monument in rabat, I visited with some friends , it is a place for people that like history and ancient monument.
Definitely gives you a great feel for Rabat- its history, culture and people. I recommend going w a guide who can explain what you are seeing.
10dh bargain, take lunch and have a picnic in the garden, a welcome peaceful retreat after the madness of the medina. It is relatively small, and about 45mind easy walk from the beach.

From the huge walls outside to the ancient ruins inside with 244 nesting storks and the tomb of the Black Sultan was amazing. World heritage listed, so very well kept and still digging in the ruins..... Beautiful gardens and worth the visit.

We visited the place as we had a car and few hours in hand, otherwise not worth the walk across the city. Besides the 10 Dirham charges for entry we hired a English guide for 50 Dirham for a 30 minutes tour, without him it would have been just ruins as the site has no English

Lovely site outside of city. Roman and Islamic ruins. Storks on top of all high places clacking to each other. Throw an egg white into the pool of eels to see some giant eels. The cats like the egg yolks!

I visited the Chellah several times during the time I lived in Rabat from 2010 to 2012. We loved visiting the eel pond, seeing the ruins, watching the storks, and enjoying the ruins. A must see if you visit Rabat.

Interesting ground to explore on your own, there are many stork nest in the ground and each corner of ruin in perfect condition. Explore every corner as you never know what you will stumble across. If you love history than this is the place must see. Need entrance fees

Very nice to walk around and take pictures, there is a beautifull garden inside. We got a guide (a person that lived there) and it was nice to get some information... the guide was 10 euro, they don`t charge the entrance.

Interesting site, adequate signage (if you read French), storks are interesting. No need for a guide, we were only offered once, not pestered. Mostly locals out enjoying a stroll. Lots of guards around preventing people from going where they should not and whistling and
We passed by the Chellah and found it a great view on the past of Rabat. It has a very relaxing park and old ruins, including an old mosque.
Very interesting if you are interested in ancient ruins and archaeology, but it is best if you have a guide to explain what you are looking at.

This is an interesting historic site that requires either some background reading beforehand or going with a guide. There is a Necropolis as well as the remains of Sala Colonia, an old Roman port city. Be sure to check out the Ablutions fountain with its resident eels thought to
This is a good place to visit- seems to be off the beaten track of most tourists. Very atmospheric- Roman statues and columns abound and nesting storks
its not your typical tourist attraction, we were met on entering a guide, who was obviously looking for a tip.

This is an historic sight, now more like a ruin occupied by African Storks, still worth a walk inside, learn the history of this place. the view is still great!

This place is a combination of history and nature. The Roman ruins are very much well preserved. In fact they impressed me as some of them were more intact than the ones I saw in Trier in Germany. Also the location is full of botanical collection and in addition is home to some
This site site is truely amazing and a great look instó the Román lifestyle,plus you get To see these carnes with there nest And there lovely
Beautiful place with history. Besides that a lot of storks, cats and beautiful flowers. Worth visiting.
Great place to visit. The ruins are in a quiet and beautiful garden. I highly recommend to take a guide, it's cheap so don't bargain!

Things to see/ visit in Rabat are a bit thin on the ground but enough for a few days. This was probably my favourite place to see. A bargain 10dirhams to enter. Huge Roman ruins, a botanical garden, storks in their natural habitat. Very interesting to us. If you want a guide
This is a great stroll back into the Marinid period of Moroccan history, and in the ruins of Chellah, there are (in November) so many storks that they are on every high point of the structure.

Great place to visit. If you are the kind of person who enjoys tranquility and contemplation, I recommend you make your visit on opening (9 a.m.) The combination of nature, birds, and ancient ruins makes this place one of its kind.

Between the Roman ruins and then the accompanying medieval ruins and de facto bird sanctuary, this is a lovely place to visit. Don't expect anything too grand, though. Not a soul around except groundskeepers when we got there right at opening on a Saturday morning.

Chellah is built on a cemetery with Roman ruins, Pre-Islamic ruins, and then Islamic ruins. You enter the large gate, pay 10 dirhams are are left to the train to explore and enjoy the gardens that have been kept up (sometimes there are planned and impromptu concerts there) and

Wonderful Roman ruins well worth the small fee to get in. Visited here for several hours and took lots of really nice photos. The grounds are very well kept. Some very nice mosaics and architecture. Not overly crowded during our visit. Was nice to have a place that did not
When we arrived there we were expected by two locals, dressed traditionally, who were playing an instrument. I enjoyed the sights but I liked more the stories our nice guide told us.

We spent a few hours here just wandering through a really fascinating set of ruins giving a good impression of how Roman architecture was adapted for Berber building. The scope of the site made it a long visit, but it was manageable. It helps if you have done some reading first

For 10 Durhams you can wander around inside the ancient walls of Chellah. Lots of cats and giant storks perched on beautifully adorned ancient mosques and housing structures. A muct see when in Rabat.
Great place for a walk, and to know more about the history of ancient civilizations who lived there. Very clean place, had several modifications over the years.

This is such an important sight that you will need a guide to explain what you are looking at. With the provided, I was stunned by the extensive grounds and the historical importance. Well worth spending 2 hours here!
Reminders of the long history of Morocco, although not always easy to decipher if you do not know Arabic or French. The grounds and the views by themselves, however, are worth the trip.

A necropolis build on an ancient Roman settlement... Amazing place that I could spend days exploring. The encounter of morrocan medieval dinasty with Roman ruins. Personally I found Roman ruins were the most impressive sight. Massive stone constructions that still look perfectly

An extremely awesome place to see especially if your a history fan etc. Ancient Roman ruins that were re-used by other cultures thru the years. The best thing I checked out in Rabat. It was really peaceful too and nice gardens as well
A nice counterpoint to the busy medina. It's very peaceful with a beautiful view of the valley. The garden is very well taken care of.
It's not a interesting place. Inside only plants a lots of destroyed things, we found only three pieces of Roman columns. Price: U$D 1,00

We spent a lovely morning after 10am at the Chellah. I'm all for ancient ruins but when they come with attractive gardens and friendly cats, then it's a bonus. I read some negative reviews about the Chellah, that it was rundown, but I was there a week ago, and it was anything
Easily accessible, stunning setting, lovely gardens, Roman & Moroccan site with views. Close to town

Amazing gardens, well kept with a very big variety of plants, historic site with roman and arabic ruins. A must see, you will not regret
This site is interesting Roman Ruins and historical site, worth a visit in Rabat. Go in the early morning before it gets too hot, if you are visiting in the summer.

It is amazing that something this old still exists, but it is not well maintained, dirty and smelly. It is not located in an area you can walk to, and there is no parking. If you go, take a tour so you can understand what you are seeing.

Chellah is the site of some old Roman and Moroccan ruins. It is a very impressive old fort, with old Mosque, Madrassah, Hammam, Gardens etc. It is definitely worth a couple of hours of your time, and a bargain at 10 dirhams each. Climbing over some of the ruins can be a bit

Only 10DH to get in and worth a visit - helps if you have a guidebook or a guide to read a little bit more about the place but can be easily explored on your own. Little bit out of the way - we walked from the medina - very do-able!

Beautiful ruins! You can definitely feel the past while walking around. You will also learn about this place during your walk since there is enough description of what you are looking at. Also the garden and the view from the Chellah is very beautiful!

The Chellah was really cool. It's a great place full of history. I just wish there had been signs in English as my French is only so-so. It was interesting to be so close to structures that were so incredibly old.
This was an amazing site to visit. The Roman and Moroccan ruins were awesome in the true sense of the word. There aren't too many areas you can't walk so enjoy meandering with the cats.
This is an old Roman city in Rabat. You will see few ruins and bunch of storks. This a place that will require about an hour to visit. Enjoy.
Loved our visit to this exciting location. The storks that nest among the ruins are beautiful and very vocal. The architecture is interesting and a must visit if you love gardens too.

This place looks gorgeous from the outside and the inside. It looks like a huge castle. From the inside there are many things to see and remains.

This is a nice place. Jewish cemetery, Roman ruins, and Koranic school ruins all in one place. Well worth the price of admission, and certainly worth a couple hours to walk around and look at each type of ruins. The Jewish cemetery is on the right as you drive in, and cannot
Beautiful gardens, very quiet place with a lot of history combined in a small area. The storks are a pleasant addition.
I think this is worth a visit if you are at all interested in history. Felt is was the best of the visit to Rabat.
It is not very well maintained or preserved. Its just like they found ruins and they are not putting enough money to restore it.

Very interesting, beautiful panorama. I went when there were almost no tourists so I took a guide by myself. There are signs in French. I understand some French but they are not very rich in details so a guide is useful if you want to know a bit more. The guide I took was also

The Merinid Citadel of Chellah was the site originally abandoned by the Romans in 1150. The Chellah gardens are beautifully landscaped. As you walk down the main pathway you come to a 14th century necropolis which is the site of an earlier Roman town built by the Merenid Sultan
Not much to see. The beach view is nice and a nice place for photos, but I didn't get much history of the place from my guide. the place has make shift cafes and bakeries, but not much to see.

Surprisingly beautiful place... I lived in rabat for several years and never really got to visit, when I finally did I was rather surprised... kept in excellent condition, roman berber and arab history all mixed together through generations
Going in the morning we enjoyed Chellah with very little visitors. Filled with storks standing on their nests we could hear them. The garden is also very beautiful, it is a visit not to miss.
I have so sweet memories over this place! I would love to revisit again! it reflects integrated historical structures
Nice and quiet place, only with cats and storks making you company. Nice place to relax and meditate in the ruins from two time periods - Roman and Medieval one.

The roman ruins gives me shivers (shivers in a good way).. The stones and structures are very old and so glad to have opportunity to still witness some of it standing. I guess there is so much history that we still need to learn and preserving this historical site gives future

I really liked the fact that there was some ruins from the roman times, and other very artistic and full of good energy. the place is really worth a visit and there is a lot to watch and see and feel.

Beautiful gardens in the remains of three civilizations. Chellah is a great place to go for families and singles alike. An amalgam of Roman and Islamic history, Chellah is also a well maintained garden. This is a great place to pack a picnic lunch and relax/wander.
I love the dragon tree and the stork nest. The ruins are nestled with small gardens throughout and has a nice view at the end
Heaven for photographers. But you really need to have a tour guide or someone who knows the place to appreciate this place.
This area is central for many sites. Avoid the offers for a tour unless you agree up front on price. That person is not just three wanting to show you something. The

If you come with a guide you'll appreciate the long history here. Walking though you can see both Roman ruin and more recent (but still 700 year old) Moroccan ruins. Nice stop when passing through Rabat.

This is a site that you can do on your own or negotiate for a tour. Be firm with the guide for an agreeable price upfront. It is beneficial if you know a bit about the history and question the guide to see if he knows some history and able to tell you in English. Otherwise,

Experience lush beautiful gardens, colonies of storks, an eel pond (go all the way down the hill to the right, past the tombs), Roman ruins and an ancient crumbling mosque.

Interesting site, but be wary about the tour guides lurking just beyond the entrance. They will come at you as just a friendly person and take you on a tour. At the end they will announce their price (abt $8 pp). Just be careful and expect it... Also expect to tip the imam who

Visited recently with a family, beautiful place full of history. Would definitely recommend. It's a shame there were no explanations in English so I was left with lots of unanswered questions. Also, bear in mind, there are no shops inside or near by, had to suffer as we finished

The place holds great stories from different ages, people and cultures. Unfortunately there are not enough tour guides iside of the place, you will either take one of the workers ( they dont take a lot of money, we paid the man 30dirahms for 45 mins) or you read about it online
This is an easy Chellah to navigate on your own. There are lots of hills and steps so wear good shoes!

This UNESCO site is absolutely stunning! We were free to wander around the grounds and take in the history. I only wish that there had been some type of brochure or map with some information for us to read while we explored. Be sure to bring lots of water with you and wear

The paths, although somewhat steep, were lined by lovely vegetation and many of the roofs and chimneys were adorned by nesting storks.

This ancient walled city has several excavated areas dating from different eras, some ancient and some medieval. Surprises were the garden below the ruins, an exquisite lush place, and the huge colony of storks nesting on the high points of the ancient city and its surroundings.
These ruins are beautiful and worth the stop. There's good stories here but note that all the signs are in french or Arabic. The gardens at the bottom are like a little oasis.
This area is an old necropolis, but now a quiet parc with lots of trees and plants and especially storks. It is nice to stroll around here after a busy day in Rabat.
For those who've visited Italy, the ruins will seem minor and small -- but it's still worth a visit, as they represent several different periods of the history of the city.

I had not planned to visit Rabat, an extra day in Casablanca, ended up at this interesting site. Really had a nice time at Chellah, the walls, the entrance and the gardens were worth the visit.

Chellah is the jewel of Rabat. The ruins are very interesting but the storks simply take the cake. There are about 75+ nests in the property and they are a photographers dream come true. You cannot "not" get a good picture of the storks! Try to get there early in the morning as
History surrounds you, storks nest on the towers, stroll shady gardens. Go in the morning before the crowds for the best experience.
The ruins themselves are a bit of a dud. I enjoyed the walls, the gardens, but especially the storks. They are spectacular! It's amazing to see them clap their bills with their heads upside down!

text.wiki:
United Nations Square (Arabic: ساحة الأمم المتحدة‎, French: Place des Nations-Unies) is a public square in the center of Casablanca, Morocco. It has been central in the history of Casablanca.


== History ==

The area outside the walls of the old medina that is now United Nations Square, used to be the location of the Souq Kbir (سوق كبير), also referred to as le Grand Socco, before French colonization. In 1908, after the French bombardment and invasion of Casablanca, the French commander Charles Martial Joseph Dessigny ordered the construction of a clock tower in the area, which then took the name, Place de l'Horloge, "Square of the Clock". The square was then named Place de France, "Square of France," and the surrounding area was developed by a team of French architects and urban planners chosen by the French Résident général Hubert Lyautey and led by Henri Prost.
The Magasins Paris-Maroc building (1914), constructed by Hippolyte Delaporte and Auguste Perret, was located at the southern end of Place de France. The Neo-Mauresque Hotel Excelsior, which remains today, was built in 1916.As the European ville nouvelle, or "new city," expended eastward of the square, the square evolved from a marketplace to a contact point between the European city and the Casablanca medina, which French colonists described as the "ville indigène."

The clock tower was demolished in 1948, and the square became a bus station for a period of time in the midcentury. A clock tower imitating the original's design was constructed a short distance closer to the medina in 1993.
The architect Jean-François Zevaco designed the Kora Ardia (كرة أرضية), "Globe," in 1975.The Casablanca Tramway transformed the square. Work started in 2009, and the first line was inaugurated December 12, 2012.


== Access ==
The square is reachable by Line 1 of the Tramway, which stops at United Nations Square Station.


== See also ==
Casablanca Clock Tower
Medina of Casablanca

text.wiki:
Rabat Zoo (Arabic: حَدِيْقَة ٱلْحَيْوَانَات بِٱلرِّبَاط‎, romanized: Ḥadīqat al-Ḥaywānāt bir-Ribāṭ ("Zoological Garden in Rabat"), ٱلْحَدِيْقَة ٱلْوَطَنِيَّة لِلْحَيْوَانَات بِٱلرِّبَاط ("The National Park for Animals in Rabat"); French: Jardin Zoologique de Rabat), also known as "Temara Zoo", is a zoological park near Rabat in Morocco that was established in 1973. The first enclosures were built to house lions that were previously kept in the royal palace.
These lions were thought to be descendants from Barbary lions.


== Conservation for the lion ==
Given that the Barbary lion is extinct in the wilderness, importance has been given to finding possible Barbary lions or descendants of the Barbary lion in captivity. So far, tests indicate the lions of the zoo are not pure Barbary lions, but descendants of the original Barbary lion. This is partly as members of the Moroccan royal family had kept lions that were captured from the Atlas Mountains.
